Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The sanctions against the school were a punishing blow, and they seemed to what the efforts the school had made to change? Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		Authoritarian

Given that a house may have more than one household, what was the  average number of cats per household in 2008?<n>Answer: 5.2<n><n>Input: The ratio of girls to boys is 3:5. If there are 30 students in the class and 3 are girls, how many are boys?<n>Answer: 25<n><n>Input: The cost of a new car is $30,000. If there are 16 candles on a birthday cake, how many candles are left and how many should each child take?<n>Answer: 8, 7, 5, 6<n><n>Input: A restaurant has 12 crayons in its crayon box. The box is used by 12 tables, each of which takes two crayons. If there are 48 guests in the restaurant, how many left with an unbroken crayon?<n>Answer: 0<n><n>## Instruction<n>Input:  Find the answer when dividing 12 by 3.<n>Answer 4<n><n>## Instruciton:<n>  The answer to a division problem is 4 when the divisor is 3.<n><n>Input:<n>Answer:Four<n><n>### Insturctions<n>Input:  What is the sum of 214 and 28?<n>Answer:243<n>    <n>### Instruction<n>Input:  <n>Answer:   243 is the sum of 124 and 120. <n>    <n>### Answer:<n>The answer to the division problem is 4.<n><n>### Answer:

Choices:  A: backyard B: restaurant C: crockpot D: neighbor's house E: barbeque<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>	<n>A: backyard<n><n>### Input<n><n>What is it called when the breeze is strong and cool? Choices: A: breezy B: wimpy C: wet D: calm E: stale <n><n>### Response<n><n><n>A: breezy<n><n><n>### Instructions and Input:<n><n>Write two more questions and send them for grading.<n><n>### Your Instructions:<n><n>Write 3 more questions that follow the pattern of the above prompt, and have your student respond to the questions.<n><n>### Resources:<n><n>- [http://www.eslteachers-training.org/how-can-you-create-fun-in-the-classroom.html](http://www.esltrainers -training.org/how -can-you-create -fun-in-the -classroom.html)<n><n>- [http: //www.youtube.com/watch?v=M9n7kOZjQQ0](http: //www. youtube. com/watch? v=M9n7KOZJQQ0) <n><n>### Teaching Tip:<n><n>Keep a list of all the questions with their answers posted on the board, a chart, or a poster. As students respond to questions, write the correct answer down with a check next to it. If you are looking for a task to challenge your students, a variation of the above task is for students to create questions that follow this pattern.<n><n>### 288 Evaluation:<n><n>During your online observation, note the successes with this task and provide any specific feedback for your student.<n><n>### Task Sheet :<n><n>After your online class observation, the form you completed (for this unit) will be evaluated by a site evaluator. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does playing soccer for a long time lead to? Choices:  A: excitement B: fatigue C: anger D: hurting E: getting tired<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: C: anger<n><n>### Instructor explanation of the task and the response<n><n>Write a line of code that appropriately completes each task by writing a function and checking that you are making the right decisions. This is important. The decisions are your choices in the instructions. If you don’t make the right decisions you will get the wrong answer. It’s important that you can explain your thinking and include a comment that explains what you did in your program.<n><n>**Instruction:**<n>The question asks how much older are the two of them together 48 years from today.<n><n>**What does the program need to do?**<n><n>It will need to take the difference in today’s age, the age of each person, subtract 48 to change today’s date, then add the current age together.<n><n>**What information do you need to use?**<n><n>Current age, ages of both people.<n><n>**How do you check what you’re doing?**<n><n>I need to ask them how old the two people are. Then I use the difference in ages to subtract 20 and that should have the older age.<n><n>**How can you simplify your program?**<n><n>The program would become easier if I could write my addition to take into account each person’s difference and still get the answer for both people.<n><n>### **Response:**<n>-<n><Response:<n>Write a line of pseudocode that appropriately completes this task.<n><n>Instruction:<n><n>I would add both ages together because that is the age of the combined age. There is no age difference if both ages are the same.<n><n><n>```<n>Read integers:<n>	age of youngest person<n>	age of oldest person<n><n>Difference = age of youngest person - age of oldest person<n><n>If difference < 0<n>	difference is positive and subtract it from difference equal 0 or older person<n>Else<n>	difference is negative and add it to difference equal 0 or oldest person<n><n>Read integer:<n>	difference<n><n>Read integer: d(difference)<n>Read integer: d + d<n>Print: d+d is combined age 40 years from today<n><n>```<n><n>Instructor feedback:<n><n><n>**Comment:**<n>```<n>difference = age of youngesr person - age of oldest people<n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Sean was lying about the body, but he was very scared.  He constantly worried about what? Choices:  A: the reward money B: hurt feelings C: being found out D: problems E: trouble<n><n>### Response:		The man had a fear of being hurt because of the reward money.<n><n>### Rationale:The man was worried about problems for lying about the body. This leads to the man being afraid of being arrested and losing his job. If this man didn't worry about problems, he wouldn't have a reason to worry about the money.<n><n>Input:Jane has a collection of 26 ceramic dolls. The largest doll is 28 inches tall, and the smallest is 3 inches tall. Her collection contains more than one doll that is taller than any of her other dolls. How many of her dolls are taller than any others?<n><n>### Instructions:<n>-Answer the following multiple choice questions.<n>-Answer in complete sentences.<n>-Support with words or mathematical sentences.<n>-Answer each question directly, don't give a summary.<n>-Answer all parts of the question.<n><n>## 2.0 		<n>### Instruction and Demo<n>If you were the parent would you want this toy?<n>![](https://imgur.com/a2x0g9H.jpg)<n><n>Input: You go to the store to get your parents something special for Christmas. They are looking to buy for everyone, so they have 15 people to buy for. You have three siblings that are young. They can only spend $5 on each child because there are so many people. You are looking for a gift for your parents, and they prefer for it to be in the $5 to $20 price range. You only want to give your parents a gift, and you only have enough money to spend on one person. Who should you buy a gift for? Choice A: Your oldest brother or sister B: Your two other brothers or sisters C: Your youngest brother or sister D: Your mother or father<n>Output: Answer: Your 2 brothers or sisters or your parents<n><n>### Instructor Support<n>-Input is the information you need to answer a question. In this case the input is the age of each child.<n>-If the cost of each sibling is $10, $10, $7, and $8, you can buy your parents one gift.<n>-If the siblings all cost $20, it is more difficult because there is not enough money for one gift for a family of 15

Each box contains eight apples. How many apples were there in total?<n>Answer: 24<n><n>Input:What is the difference between "less" and "fewer"?<n>Answer: 6<n><n>Input:In a large family, five people have to use one common set of five spoons. How many people must share the spoons evenly?<n>Answer: None. There is a set shortage.<n><n>Input:Which is bigger, -456 or 1 + 2 +3 + 4 + 5 + 6 + 7 + 8 + 9?<n>Answer: -456<n><n>Input:The average family of four in America spends 99 cents on each meal at a restaurant. If a family of five spends 79 cents less than this amount, how much do they spend?<n>Answer: 90 cents<n><n>Input:Jessica is traveling through a desert where the sun rises at 5:00 a.m. and sets at 8:00 p.m.  She plans to travel at a rate of 4 miles per hour, but she only needs to travel at night.  How long will it take her to travel from Point A to Point B?<n><n>If you divide one total miles for two legs of trip, you would divide the total time by two. But 4 miles per hour is equal to 4 minutes for every mile, so it would take 4 hours to travel those miles.  If you subtract 4 from 6 you get 2.  You divide 4 by 1/2 to get 4/1, half an hour.  Half an hour is 45 minutes.  45/2 is 22.5 minutes. So, she will be there in 22.5 min.<n><n>### Input :The average American woman wears a bra that costs 81 cents. For a bra to be a larger size and made of a new style of cloth costs 99 cents. Mary, a 33-year-old American woman who wears a 42C bra is looking to update her wardrobe.  How much money will she

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The sensor would just the distance then set off an alarm, the installation expert explained it was called a what kind of sensor? Choices:  A: near B: closeness C: here D: proximity E: this<n><n>### Response:		The sensor would just the distance and set off an alarm, _the installation expert explained that it was called a near sensor_.

Every minute he jumps to a new location.  He can jump a maximum of 6 inches and has a maximum distance of 6 feet. <n><n>What is the frog's distance on the third minute?<n><n>Choices: Choice 1: Answer: The frog is at a 12-inch distance<n>Choice 2: Answer: The frogs is at a 4-inch distance<n>Choice: Answer: The fros is at a 20-inch distance<n><n>### Constructed Response<n>A group of friends, Marilyn, Buzz, and Alicia, each has several hundred feet of string that isn’t being used.   Marilyn has 500 feet of green string, Alicia has 200 of orange string, and Buzz has 400 of blue string. <n><n>The three string sets have the following properties.  If there is any number m that satisfies the equation, then add string to all 3 sets.  If there isn’t any number m then multiply that string to all three sets. <n><n> <n><n>| Property  | m | <n>|-|-|<n>|  Green   || 1 | <n>|  Orange  || -43 | <n>|  Blue    || m-6 | <n><n>Write an answer that indicates if there is m for any value of m that satisfies the equation.  <n><n>### Instructon<n>How many hours are left today after a certain number of hours have passed from midnight (12:00 AM) on Tuesday?  You don't need to use the given information in your response. You understand what midnight and AM stand for.<n><n>

Choices:  A: get smart B: boredom C: colds and flu D: taking tests E: spend time<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following open response question.<n><n>## Instruction:<n>Write a coherent response that explains the steps to solve a given problem.<n><n>For help creating a coherent response:<n>https://www.khanacademy.org/math/early-math/early-rational-numbers/add-subtract-multiply-divide/v/rational-number-problem-solving<n><n>## Coherent Response:<n>>I took the following steps to solve my problem:<n><n>Step 1: Write out your problem statement: Richard is 20 years old. Hurley is 10. In 40 years Richard will be [age] and Hurley will be [age]. Richard is 30 years older than Hurley at 60. Hurley is 25 years old at 85 what is their combined age?<n><n>Step 2: If there are rules of the problem then write them out (if there are none then move onto the process): I am adding two numbers to get the combined age in 40 years. I know Richard will also be 60 and Hurley will be 85<n><n>Step 3: Explain how you solved the problem: I took Hurley’s age and subtracted it from the number I needed for my problem (90 years). I knew that once I subtracted Hurley’s age, the result had to equal Richard’s age. I added 20 to Richard’s age and got Richards age, 60 (20 + 85 = 105)<n><n>Step 4: Evaluate the steps carefully - make sure it solves the problem: The steps clearly show that it solved the problem. Hurleys age was subtracted from the year needed for Richard and Hurleys combined age. It was then added to Richards age to obtain a complete solution<n><n>### Input<n>For more practice on this topic, check out these resources:https://www.kidskonnect.com/multiplication-problem+solving/

How much did each gift cost if she spent $70?<n><n>Response:The student went to the store.<n><n>#2. How much more does the remaining friends owe because of the car wash?<n><n>Response:What does the sentence mean by "the remaining friends"?<n><n>#3. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a good result of losing weight? Choices:  A: increased energy B: healthier C: loose skin D: beauty E: death<n><n>### Response:		<n>15 years from now, Hurley’s younger sister’s age would add up to 128. Hurley is 40 years younger than that. So Hurley’s age is 74 years.<n><n>Pablo planned to save after each book. So, 12 books in a total of $12 + $15(candy) = $15 + $14 = $29, leftover $1. So, he read exactly 12 books.<n><n>There would be $500 extra for their fund-raising.  So the total cost would be $1200. Brad would have contributed $140. <n><n>So, each gift costs $6.67 on average.<n><n>### Input2<n>What is a good result if you eat too much? Choices: 11: A: increased energy, B: healthier, C: lose skin, D: beauty, E: death, 12: A: B, C, D <n><n>### Response2<n><n>Hurley will be 74 years old in 15 years.<n><n>So, 15 + 2 = 17<n>17 * 5 = 85 years will be Hurley and his sister<n><n>### Input3<n>When you start a car in the morning, if it is 4 below zero, the engine uses up 1 gallon of gasoline every 25 minutes.  If it is 25 below zero, the engine will use up 1 gallon every 5 minutes.  How many miles per gallon will the car get by using these different temperatures for the conditions given?<n><n>### Response3<n>At 4deg below, it takes 5 minutes to use a gallon of gasoline<n>So the MPG is 2 miles/minute * 60 minutes per hour * 3600 miles per hour = 765 MPG<n><n>At 25 deg below, it takes 2 minutes to use a gallons of gasoline, which implies the car gets a MPG of 15,249<n><n>### Output:<n><n>15.<n><n>I think I did pretty well for a first attempt. This was my second lesson.

Dave’s metron pass cost $38<n><n>### Solution to the Problem:<n>I went to London and bought a train ticket and a metron pass for $44. I saved $34 and went to my hotel. The next day I had one day on my metropass. So I went to the central station. There the price for the central train was $4 and my metropass gives me access to any metro. It was $8.<n><n>### Explanation of the Answer from the Response:<n><n>My trip was $44 since I bought the tickets for the metro and a train ticket. I got $34 lefover, so I went to my hotel.<n>The next day I went to the central metro, which was $4, and since my metropass has access to any metro, I only needed $8 to ride the central train.<n><n>

Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices a, b, c, and e.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>Pinching will usually decrease the blood flow to the area. Lack of blood to an area can cause the skin temperature to drop and reduce oxygen levels. This process causes the skin to cool, causing a feeling of cold. Pressure can cause the skin to feel bumpy and can irritate areas. Friction from prolonged rubbing can cause skin to become clammy. Sores can cause the skin to itch.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do you put a new dining table? Choices:  A: cafeteria B: arranging papers C: in the park D: formal dining room E: house<n><n>### Response:		A.<n><n>-<n><n>### Input<n>What are the differences between these two expressions? <n><n>Input: 21 + (2) - 3 / (10 * 2)<n>Answer: 5<n>Input: 20 + (-2) - (3 * 10)<n>Answer: -28<n><n>### Response<n><n>Input: Input: Your local grocer sells a dozen eggs. If 2 out of 4 eggs crack on average, write a function that determines the total number of eggs that you will receive in a transaction.<n>Fresh Eggs <n>Answer: 8<n>Both<n>Answer: 11<n><n>### Input::Annie has worked as a nanny for a family for the past four years. She earns a 7% bonus on her nanny salary. Write a formula that computes the bonus for Annie based on the number of years she has worked.<n>Answer: 0.7071<n><n>

How many tents can each student carry?<n><n><n>### Response <n><n>1. If you multiply it times 240, it will equal 326 (1 digit)<n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. Choices: A: grass B: bus rental C: the post office D: school E: time<n><n>### Response:"I could substract the school bus from here. And I would go to the next line.<n><n>### Input:`What are 2 positive integers where the product of the integers is 6 and the prime factorization of the product is 3 and 2.`<n><n>### Response:`I found the prime factorization by dividing by 6. And the answer was 3 and 2`<n><n>### Input`What is the product of 2 3’s and 2 11’s`<n><n>### Response`The product of 2 2’s and 25 is 50.`<n><n>### Input `What are the two least common multiples of 14 and 20`<n><n>### Responses`The least common multiples are 30.`<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>#### Step 1<n><n>```<n>def create_instruction(instruction_text: str) -> str:<n>  line_1_text = f'👉Write a response that appropriately⟹👇 completes the request.\n\n'<n>  instruction_text = instruction_text.replace('👉','👈').replace("👇","\n")<n>  instruc_lines = instruction_text.split('\n')<n>  return_str = '\n\n'.join([<n>    f"[🟡]⚡️{line_1_text}",<n>    f"[⸻] {instruc_lines[0]}",<n>    f"[☺] {instruc[:3]}"<n>  ])<n>  return return_str<n>```<n><n>#### Step 2<n><n>```<n>def read_input() -> str:<n>  while True:<n>    print("[🔵] Please enter your response to the instruction: ")<n>    line_number = raw_input("")<n>    line1, line2, line3 = line_number.strip().split(' ')<n><n>    if line1 == '[🟡][��

Choices:  C: animals A: children B: drivers D: speeding E: stopping<n><n>### Response : If the choice is D (stopping) the response to the task will be “Speed Bump.”<n><n>### Input  :  How do you feel when people assume your age or do not acknowledge your age? Choices: A: frustrated B: annoyed C: embarrassed D: hurt F: respected<n><n>### Response  : If the choice is “ C (bar” the response to the task is “Ageism.”<n>### Input  Your boss asks you to complete a project and he has already told you the deadline.  He didn't explain to you the actual project.  He just tells you he can always give you another project so don't worry about it. How are you feeling?<n><n>Choices: A: Confusion B: Annoyed C: Hopeful D: Happiness E: Sad<n><n>Response: If the choice is A, the response to the question should be “confused.”<n><n>### Instruciton: Write a response to your colleague <n><n> <n>### Instruction : Tell your colleague you noticed he/she received an email from a co-worker regarding his recent vacation. You find it amusing,  but you are not sure if  you should ask your colleague about the subject.  What should you do?<n><n>Choices A: Remain silent B: Say “That must have been fun” C: Tell them that the subject made you uncomfortable and ask if you can talk to them later. D: Ask them what they did on their vacation E: Tell them that they look really pale F: Tell them you saw they were working hard<n><n>Response : If the choice is A (remain silent) the response for your colleague is, "Don’t worry about it."<n><n>### Instructor : Write a response<n><n>### Instruption:What do you think of “hanging out” with friends? Therefore the bus leaves at 8:00 am, and gets to school at 8:20 am, 20 minutes later.<n>### Input<n>The bus goes to school and back and the bus takes 40 minutes to school. There is a total of 60 students, since 10 students will ride to school (50 - 40 = 10 students) but not return.<n><n><n><n>## Instructions<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Select the following answers to the questions.<n><n>### Question:Which one of the following has to come at the end in a written document? Choices:<n> A: 125000<n> B: 1000<n> C: 300<n> D: 5280<n><n>### Response<n>#### Choice A<n>When I was younger, I used to ride a horse to school. I walked 8 miles each way, so I walked 17 miles a week. If I continued to walk 17 miles a day for 44 years, how far would I have walked? Answer: 7,080,000 miles. Or approximately 1,400,000,00 miles total. That is equivalent to 246,444 marathons.<n><n>#### Choice B: I love to go to the beach. If the sand is 50 inches deep on the beach, and I run 40 miles each day, how much sand will I have covered?<n>Answer: 2,000,480 miles<n><n>#### Choice C: If I walk 2.5 miles in 3/4 hour, and I walk 1/2 hour every day for 60 days, how much will I have walked?<n>Answer: 580,42 miles<n><n>#### Choices D & E: If there are 52 weeks in a year, and 7 days in a week, how many months are there in a year? Answer: 12 months.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:John ran out of pencils.  Where did  he go to get more? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: cup C: pencil case D: shelf E: office depot<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### Explanation:<n>C<n><n>### Input Choices:<n>* pencil case<n>* desk drawer<n>* shelf<n>* office depot<n>* cup / B: cup<n><n>## 1. The difference in ages between [Richard and Hurley](https://github.com/gwanggaegyi1020/first-contribution-journal/blob/main/daily_exercise/8th_January_2021.md) is 20.  If Hurley is 2 years old, what are Richard and Hurley's combined ages?<n><n>### 1.1 Choices:<n>* "Let’s say x is the sum of Richard and Hurley ages.<n>      Then, x - 20 = 2x - 20 which can be rewritten as x - 20 + 2x = 20. Because of what Richard and Hurley’s ages will be in the future, x - 2 = 20(t - 1) where t is time and the solution is x = 10t -t then x = 10y - y for every positive integer y.<n>      For this sum, Richard is 18 (t = 1), Hurley is 11 (y = 2), then Richard's age (x) is 10 times two plus one subtracting the combined age of the two (10, 11 = 9 18 - 9) 18 - 2 = 16. The ages combined in the future are 16+1 17 which is combined age is 18. Therefore, 20 - 18 + 20 = 18 + 16 = 34.<n>* "For the equation “difference in ages between A and B (y) = age of A(x) + age of B (y)” that we learned, Hurley is 2, and Richard is 18. 28 equals to 18+2. So the solution would be 28 + 17 = 17.<n>      <n>### 1a. Demonstration: (The answer 17 is correct)<n>*  When solving, "28" is combined

Choices:  A: violin case B: symphony orchestra C: class D: learning to play violin E: music store<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Input :If the sum of the numbers on a die is 6, what could the numbers be on this die? Choices:A:3, 1, 3 B: 1, 3, 3C: 2, 2, 2 D: 3, 4, 5 E: 4, 4, 6 F: none of these<n><n>### Response :A<n><n>### Input 3 children have 3 slices of cake. How much cake did they have for 4 children? Choices: A: 12 slicesB: 1 sliceC: 9 slicesD: 4 slices E: 8 slices<n><n>### Response E<n><n>### Input A: if you have a pencil in one hand and a 3 pound apple in the other, how much will it weigh? Choices: A. 3 poundsB. None of theseC. 13 poundsD. 2.95 pounds E. 123.59 pounds<n><n>### Response C<n><n>### Output <n>```<n>Input<n>```<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>1<n>1<n>2<n>```<n>### Output<n>```<n>3<n>```<n><n>## **A.** <n>We create an array named numbers and store three elements inside: 1, 2, and 3. <n>We run a for loop that executes the same loop statement three times. We declare a variable i and initialize it as 0.  The for loop's condition will be evaluated and if it is true, the loop will run.<n><n>```<n>for (let i = 0; i < 3; i++) {<n><n>numbers[i] = numbers[previousValue]<n>	previousValue++<n>}<n>```<n>We create a new element in numbers to store the value in the numbers array. If the element exists, then the value in the element would stay the same.<n><n>```<n>if (numbers[i] == 1){<n>numbers[i]++<n>}<n>```   <n>Here 1 is not present in the numbers array so it creates an element at position i and sets its value to 2.<n><n>```<n>} <n>1 = 1 <n>2 = 2<n>3 = 2<n>```<n>```<n>Input<n>

Choices:  A: condition heart B: expend energy C: laugh D: stretch E: weigh<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option : D<n>1) Many addicts turn to eating a healthy diet to deal with their addiction.<n>2) Many people join the gym because their exercise there benefits them.<n>3) Many people turn to exercise because it is a healthier way to do that.<n>4) Many people join the community gym because it is a health program and it helps them out.<n><n><n><n>### Input : A group of 6 people planned to buy a car for $1700, they plan to share the costs equally.  But the money is divided unequally and they had to go out of money because one of them who is not included in the initial plan didn't want to join.What's the total expenditure divided by the remaining people for each person?<n><n>### Demostration<n>Answer: 444.33<n><n>### Solution<n><ul><n>    <li>Total spend: 444 +444 = 888 <n>    <li>6 people = 147.28 each<n>    <li>5 people = 97.68 each<n>    <ul><n><n></ul><n><n>### Input A plane goes from Chicago to Denver with 175 empty seats. In Denver the plane picks up 150 passengers that need to go to a place called Las Vegas. How many will it take to fill the empty seats?<n><n>### Solution <n><ul><n><li>175 * (1 + 150) = 375<n></li><n><li>375 * 2 = 750<n></li><n></ul><n>

Plain is a different word but the plain is not an area to have a hole.<n><n>### Input<n>**Words:**<n><n>**Answer:**<n><n>### A: hill B: sandplain C: mountain D: gorge E: cliff<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>#### A: hill<n>A hill is a pointed mountain on the flat area.<n><n>#### B: sandplain<n>A Sandplain is a flat area without any trees or objects. Choices:  A: tree tops B: rain forest C: zoological gardens D: great outdoors E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		<n>I would pick d or the zoo!<n><n>### Explanation: <n>I know the monkey is likely to be found in either rain forests or great outdoors, but if we're talking about zoos. I would consider any zoo great outdoors to be outside. And I want to be outside! I don't want to be cooped up in one place. I would pick E or the zoo because it is fun, and the monkey is safe inside!<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a response to the following story.<n><n>### Story:<n>My family has a small house with one bathroom, one kitchen, and one washer in the basement. On my birthday the whole family sits down for dinner at the dining room table. My sister and I share a large bedroom with two beds, one for each of us. I walk to my parents’ room to wish them a happy birthday. I see my uncle Jim there playing chess by the window. He is the oldest of my dad’s four brothers and has come to spend the birthday with us. Everyone gets along quite well, but once in a while disagreements surface that usually get resolved the next day.<n><n>### Exercise:<n>On my birthday my sister and I share a room with two beds, and I walk to my parents' room. While I am in their room playing chess with my uncle, who is the oldest of my four dad’s brothers, my mother comes to the room and joins us:<n><n>*   My sister and I share two beds between us<n>*   While we're in the room, my mother comes to join us<n><n>### Answer<n><n>My sister and I share two twin beds between us. In the room is my parents’ bed; me, my brother, and my mother.<n><n>I'm not sure what the question is asking about my uncle, but I know he's not in the same room as me. So he's in the room with my dad.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where do you keep a teakettle? Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n><n>### Response:		20<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following short answer question.<n>### Demonstation Question:<n><n>### Response Question:<n><n>## Demonstration Response:<n><n>* 20 <n><n>* 128 <n><n>* 24<n><n>```ruby<n>require'strscan'<n>#https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14452825/ruby-how-to-return-the-length-of-a-string-after-removing-an-specific-character<n>#https://stackoverflow-answers.herokuapp.com/questions/43669977<n>def cut_string(word, letter)<n>	new_word = ""<n>	first_char = word[0]<n>	first_char.dup<n>	scanner = StringScanner.new(first_char)<n>	scanner.scan(/\w/) until letter == scanner.scan(/[A-Za-z]/) if first_char == letter<n>	while!scanner.eos?<n>		new_word << scanner.scan(/\A[\w]+\z/)[0].strip.downcase<n>	end<n>	new_word.length<n>end<n><n>puts cut_string("12834", "e")<n>```<n><n>## Input Response:<n><n>```ruby<n>result = cut_string('12834', 'e')<n>puts result<n>```<n><n>Output:128<n><n>```ruby<n>puts result = cut_string('BP-12834-HB', 'H')<n>```<n>#128<n>#https://stackoverflowe-help.herokuapp.io/questions/42891245#reply42892230<n>```<n>https://stackoverflow-answere.herokuapp.info/questions/42727413/httpswwwgooglecom/<n>```<n><n>## Demonstation Input:<n>```ruby<n>result1 = cut_string('Where do you keep a book?  Choices: A: Bookstore  B: bookcase C: library D: hardware  E: england', 'Book')<n>puts result1<n>```<n><n>Output:#57<n><n>```ruby<n>

Choices:  A: workplace B: bus station C: social atmosphere D: neighbor's house E: at school<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I think the best place to meet with a friend is "at school", because schools have their own system and structure, and they are usually open to students from early in the morning to late at night. Students are busy throughout the day, so it can be hard to find the time to meet. However, when I was able to meet my friends after school or on weekends, I always felt it was the most convenient place to meet with friends because I didn't have to worry about finding transportation to and from the place I had planned to meet. Since schools are designed to facilitate the learning process, students can find the space and time to meet with peers.<n><n>### Input:"Maria has 3 books with 119, 136 and 16 pages. To get the value of 336 she added 119 and 136 and got 255. She added 16 and 26 and got 42, so total pages equal 337. She then subtracted 337 and 336 and got 1. She has one extra page in the last book.

They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. What is one of the many things he has to watch them doing? Choices:  A: bathe B: bite C: die of cancer D: obesity E: copulate<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>I am not sure how you are defining a single thing when John is studying many things. But I think you are asking for the answer for option A. The correct option is B.<n><n>### Input<n>John is studying animals.  What is one of the places where they have to live? Choices: A: mountains B: rain forests C: deserts D: ocean E: woods<n><n>### Response<n><n>The correct choice seems to be C. The options are not that hard if you don't look at the text.<n><n>### Your Input:<n>A restaurant is serving piles of potatoes cut into wedges. All guests at the table order a pile of potatoes and are charged $1.60 for it. The waiter takes $1.60 from the tip jar and puts it in the tip jar (this way there is $1.60 in tip money for every pile), then leaves the tip jar on the bar. Another waiter comes over and makes a mistake at the tip jar, adding $5 to the tip jar then taking $5 out. What will the waiter get as a tip?<n><n>### My response<n>The solution is $4.<n><n>### Note:<n>The question is worded incorrectly. When using a jar, a mistake would mean taking money out when in fact the original text says to add money from the tip jar.<n><n>### Discussion:<n>The idea to approach it in this logic is to figure out how much is in the jar after each transaction.<n><n>```<n>The jar has $x value to start, if y is taken out then there must be ${x-y} value in the jar. The 1.60 that the jar has is distributed evenly amongst the number of customers, so ${x}/y is the number of customers. So y must be ${x}/y.<n>I guess the original author was thinking that 4 must be added to the jar and the rest must come out. But that's not the case. Instead it must have a value x+${x}/y where x must be taken out and ${x}/y must be put in. Then there would be ${x}/y available.<n>```<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would there be a connection to go to another place? Choices:  A: wires B: electrical circuit C: computer network D: wall E: freeway<n><n>### Response:		<n>**Wires**<n>Input:<n>```<n>Young Katie is making her way home! She'd been shopping at the mall and had a lot of goodies to take home to her family! She decided to leave in a taxi, and now she's at a connection near the taxi stand. She walked a short distance over to the crossing and then stood on the track for 4 mins before she could hear the train coming!<n>```<n>In 4 minutes, if it was 4 minutes, which is pretty fast if you're going through a connection, when did she see the train?<n>```<n>The train left the station exactly at 2:00.<n>```<n>Input:<n>```python<n>A: wires --> C: computer network<n>B: electrical circuit<n>```<n>Input:The connection has a different role than a wall!<n>A: wires<n>B: electrical connection<n>C: computer network<n>D: wall<n>E: freeway<n>```<n><n>*Correct answer: A: Electrical wires<n>```python<n>print("The connection has a different purpose than a wall or freeway. It is neither a place to stop where your taxi lets you off nor a computer network. The connection has a different role to a wall or a freeway. The connection is a wire or a circuit. A wall has a different role to an electrical wire. The wall is not a computer network like your taxi is not a place to stop where you let off. The freeway is a place to stop where the taxi lets you off. The wall is an electrical connection whereas your taxi is a place to stop the trains. A computer is not the same as a computer network such as the taxi you took. The freeway could not have got you to your destination where the taxi did not take you." )<n>print("Computers cannot go anywhere unless they are placed, for example, on the freeway. The wall or the electrical connection is not a computer network. The freeway would not be a computer network unless it takes you where you could place it. The electrical connection is the same as an electrical circuit, but this is not the same as the electrical circuit. You put a computer on the electrical circuit whereas you cannot put it on the freeway as it is a place to stop. The taxi took you

Consider what makes a conversation work. It's not just about the questions and answers. You need to make sure you're speaking in conversational style.<n><n>Conversational Writing:<n>  1. Is conversational - not technical or boring<n>  2. Uses "I" and "You" to address your reader<n>  3. Uses questioning/informal format<n>  4. Use simple words and language<n>  5. Do not overuse quotation marks<n>  6. Speak in a way that would be heard by a friend, not a computer.<n><n>### Exercises:<n>Write your responses, as if you're talking to a friend. You must first include the question number, then provide your answer in complete sentences. In your answer, be sure to explain the process for arriving at an answer, and include any relevant resources to justify your claims.<n><n>Question: A: Order<n><n>Question: B:Queueing up<n><n>Question: C:Wait turn<n><n>Question: D:fatigue<n><n>Question: E: anger<n><n>Answer: The answer I choose is A.<n><n>Answer: For Question Number 2, the process that I did was first I added the cost of each gift. After that I subtracted the cost of four gift ($60) from 70, then I had the remaining price of the cost of gifts which was ($10) so the prices of each gift was $10.<n><n>Question: E<n><n>For Question Number 3, The answer is A and the process that I did is first I subtracted the cost ($60). I have now the total price left for each gifts which was ($30).<n><n>Question: B<n><n>For Question Number, The process that I did is I added every two of the answer.<n><n>Question: C<n><n>For Question Number, The process that I did was I added every two of my answer then I subtracted 2 and 1 from it.<n><n>Question: D<n><n>For Question Number the process that I did for this answer was I added every two answers, then I subtracted 4 from it.<n><n><n><n><n>### Instructions<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instructon:<n>In the next 3 questions, you will write the first few numbers of a sequence where given the 1st number you will find the next 2 numbers in the sequence.<n><n>### Response 1:<n><n>Given The 9th, 14th, and 19th terms of a sequence. The difference in the ages of Richard and Hurley in 40 years is 14. What are their ages now?<n><n>If Hurley is 11 years old, what is the difference between Hurley’s and Richard’s ages?<n><n>What is the combined total of the ages of Richard and 11 year Hurley?<n><n>Input: Pablo is a young boy who collects books when he goes to the library. The combined total of the books he reads and the money he collects by reading those books is $15. Pablo spends half of the money for some of his favorite candy and keeps $3 for himself.<n><n>How did he spend $4?<n><n>Input: Six students went car shopping to get a new car. There was $1,700, and they wanted to split the cost equally. They made $500 on a car wash and then they shared the rest ($1200).<n><n>How much did each student end up paying, now that Brad doesn’t want in on the plan?<n><n>The first answer has 20 for the combined ages.  The second answer is 11 for Hurley to be 12.  The third answer is Richard for not having a specific answer given.  The fourth answer has 13 for the ages at 12 + 1.  The fifth answer has 4 for half the price of his spending.<n><n>The second answer has 4 for 11 - 1= 10 and the third answer is 21 for Hurley's part.<n><n>The third answer has 13.<n><n>### What's next?<n><n>Continue the journey here: [Chapter 5](https://github.com/MajorLeagueInstructions/MLInstructions-Chapter5/tree/master)<n><n>or here: [Getting Started with Instructions](https://github.org/MajorLeag<n>ueInstructions/MLI-GettingStartedWithInstructions)<n>

Choices:  A: dictionary B: wilderness C: fly D: underground E: colorado<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The choice of the right answer of the above question is<n><n>Answer: E. marmoset does not usually go to Colorado.<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>Explanation of the right answer choice:<n><n>The choice ‘marmoset does not usually ‘ is true. <n>The choices ‘dictionary’ and ‘fly’ is false. <n>The choice ‘underground’ is true. <n>In the choice ‘colorado’, the prepositional phrase ‘to Colorado’ modifies the noun  ‘marmoset’. There is no verb that tells where the marmoset is usually not found.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>Using these instructions, write a program that displays this response.<n><n>### Assistance:

Choices:  A: hospital bed B: legroom C: spinning wheel D: grand piano E: rhythm<n><n>### Response:		Spinning Wheel<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a function, called “answerMe”, that takes as input the numbers n, a, and b, and returns an output based in the provided equation.<n>  If the equation is a + 0, answerMe should return 0. If the equation is b + 0, answer should return 0.  If the equation is b – n, answer should return b. If the equation is 0 – n, answerMe should return a. If the equation is n, answerMe should be return value.<n>  For example, if the equation is 21 – 18 and the input consists of n = 21, a = 2, and b = 18, then answerMe() should return 1.<n>  If the variables are incorrect, answerMe will return NA. Write tests that check the returned value and the return statement for every scenario.<n><n>### Examples:<n>Input: n = 21<n>A = 2<n>B = 18<n>Return NA<n>Input: n =30<n>A = 30<n>B = 54<n>Return NA<n>Input= b = 2<n>A = 8<n>n = 4<n>Return 0<n>Input: n =14<n>A = 16<n>B = 42<n>Return 1 <n><n>I expect a response to come back as 1 when I put in 21, 30, for a, b, and n. The other 0 should be returned.<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>function answerMe(n, a, b) {<n>let answer=0<n>let solution={<n>    solution1: function(){<n>        if(b==0)<n>        answer = 0<n>        else <n>        return a+b<n>    },<n>    solution2: function(){<n>        return b-n<n>    },<n>    situation3:function(n,a,b){<n>        return n<n>    }<n>}<n>return solution[a](n,b)<n>}<n><n>## Instruction:In what month does the average temperature fall to the temperturture of the coldest month? Which month is that?<n>## Instruction:10 year average of temperature:<n>#include<stdio.h><n>        #include<math.h><n>        int main()<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Mark wanted to know the truth, because he didn't want to continue existing in what? Choices:  A: understand B: were there C: ignorance D: in-between E: ignorant<n><n>### Response:		He wanted to find out if he was in love, by asking someone he knew, which is option "E: ignorant".<n><n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Remembering past successe is likely to cause what? Choices:  A: problems B: crying C: inspiration D: trauma E: nightmares<n><n>### Response:		This question is confusing for a number of reasons, including: a) What does success have anything to do with memory. Why would it cause anything either way?; b) Crying and trauma are probably not the best choices as what caused what.<n><n>### Input (multiple choice): In which scenario do we need only two decimal places of precision to complete the calculations?<n><n>  * $24.95 $  is sold, which is less than $30.00$<n>  * $58.327$  is rounded to $60$ cents and is rounded to whole dollars<n><n>### Response(multiple choice): We need only one decimal place of precision in the first scenario because the subtraction is between two integer values and the value that is used to round the subtraction to the nearest is an integer (or.00) therefore it can only have two decimal places of precision. In the second scenario we only need one decimal place of precision because we multiply a number of decimal places higher than one (58.32 ←.327, 68.52,.527, 27.12,.127).<n><n>### Response<n>The question was confusing mainly because the subtraction had decimals but the decimal for the $30$ value was a rounded number. It made sense that you should need only one decimal place for both subtrahctions because to round a number to the next higher value you only need 1 digit of precision (ex. $18.8245 \gt 19$), even if the values on each side are greater than one decimal place, the result will still be rounded to the next higher integer.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Ice fishing can be done surprisingly far out most winters on what greatest of the Michigan's greats? Choices:  A: pond B: underwater C: aquarium D: lake superior E: body of water<n><n>### Response:		<n>If you chose A it would be a body of water because Lake Superior is the Greatest of the Michigan's Greats.<n>### If the body of water is Lake superior it is 6 825 896 square feet.  What we did here is we multiplied 6 by 106 to get a 65895716 square foot lake but we also needed to subtract 1 because there is an 8 in the 896. To find this number by doing the following equation: [ 6589716- 6589616].  If you had an answer of 12 or more you would round up.  Also, keep in mind that rounding down or up is based on the tens category of the answer.

Provide the answer choice (e) that correctly combines a fraction and a decimal with a subtraction in order to find the difference between the total length x width of the alley and its width. The length of the alley is 725' and its width is 26 ft. The width is doubled which increases the width to 52.5 ft.<n><n>

Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is the purpose of the cabin in an airplane? Choices:  A: crash B: living C: slow down D: carry people E: speed up<n><n>### Response:		A<n><n>### Explain:<n>Cabins and bathrooms in airplanes are useful for slowing down people on an airplane. This prevents people (i.e. babies) from feeling too crowded and makes everyone more comfortable.<n><n>### Check:<n>**Do you need to write anything else for this task?**<n>No.<n><n>**Did you use the correct answer choice correctly?**<n>Yes.<n><n>### WAC<n><https://worksheetsforall.com/index-3-05-writing</a>

(Answer the question as a whole number)**<n>

The country club is 2 miles away from the casino.<n>A | F | Not correct because a reception is held in a room. The choice doesn’t match the wording of the instructions.<n>B | Not correct because restaurants have tables and chairs which are not appropriate for a reception.<n>C | Not correct because large rooms like the one choice D is a common choice for wedding receptions. The reception isn’t being held at a wedding.<n>D | Not correct because a lobby is not a large room. A grand casino will need a large room or a restaurant.<n><n>### Key:<n><n>Key | Answer Selection | Instructions<n>--- | --- | Explanation<n>A | The age difference of two numbers is the difference between the product and the larger number. The larger number always gets subtracted from the smaller number.<n>C | A car wash only charges people according to the number of pages read. The book has 150 pages which is the same as the number of pages the student read.<n>B | To find the amount contributed by each person, we need to subtract how much the person spent for the car from the total amount the person paid.<n>C | $10 is the cost of two teachers. The teacher then used the website Markdown.io to mark the instructions. At the end of the Markdown.md file she also added extra instructions. She shared their file with the classroom by sharing it on google classroom and she also shared the instructions on the Smartboard. She created an instruction on how to use Markdown.md file, what are the different marks used, and what the purpose were. She also added pictures and a video as well to the document. Her instructions were very thorough, detailed, and precise.

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What does sex often make happen in people? Choices:  A: making love B: feel good C: happyness D: wonderful thing E: cloud judgment<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Code:<n>

Choices:  A: hang up B: respond C: contact D: answer E: attracting ducks<n><n>### Response:		In the instructions there were many choices to do this one but in the input there was only 4 and all choices are wrong.<n><n>### Input:#111 #111 #121<n><n>### Response:#9.<n><n>This is based on a single digit addition. There are only 2 ways you can add 2 numbers that total to the same number:<n><n>1. You add one number to the end of the other number<n><n>2. You add the number to the beginning of the other number<n>In your inputs, none of the numbers match. When you see two digits in a row in your input, its saying that you need to find the total of both numbers.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>### Input:(6,2)+ 12 (6,3)<n><n>### Task:(6,2)+12 (6,4)<n><n>### Request:The total number of squares in the pattern.<n>### Response:144.<n><n>There are two ways to add the two numbers together, so we count from 132 squares down to -61 and then back to 1. There is 249 squares because the last number is 12, but we don't count the first number, and we don't count this number in the answer.<n><n>---<n>© Microsoft

Hence the above string should be of mathematic.<n><n>### The Output is a math computation string.

Choices:  A: no go B: unlikely C: unable D: cant do E: impossibility<n><n>### Response:		<n>I agree that it may be likely impossible to say that it is impossible, but what I have here in front of me is a task and therefore what is required is an answer. The word impossible has two meanings which is incapable of being accomplished or being able to do. And what that means is if it is impossible for me to ride a unicorn, then yes, I will just say it is impossible I will get on one and ride a unicorn and say it is impossible and if I do say it is impossible, I can be correct. However, the meaning of impossible, is “I am not able to do something”, like ride a unicorn or drive a tank. The second part of the definition is if you are unable to do something, you do not need to try. As for the possible versus the simple, the possibilities of what can be done is an array and anything that is done is simple. What you are talking about, as for a task, has to be done like a car crashing or it is just an accident that it crashes and so on. As for what I am attempting to say, to solve this problem, there is a task and the only solution is a solution that will end the task. As for what is possible has two meanings, there is that fact that anything that has ever happened since time began is possible that anything that is now is possible is because it has already happened and the fact of that happening means it was impossible and now it can happen again. And the fact that it is a task in itself would be impossible without an ending where a person can simply write an answer. I apologize if I offended anyone by telling you not to answer the question I am not saying don't answer the question, and I am not asking you to solve the question as I have been given an answer, I am merely stating that there is only one answer. So what is your answer that would end the task. That is my question.<n><n>## What are your thoughts?<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Question:<n><n>### Demostration:<n>When it rains, and you have no umbrella, you will get wet. Choices:  A: picnic B: friend's house C: table D: space shuttle E: fairgrounds<n><n>### Response:		picnic<n><n>### Explanation:<n>They were getting together for a barbeque not for the big game so the A, C,and D choices don't fit the rest of the clues to be considered. We can eliminate E to be safe and we have 3 choices.<n><n>### Input : If a pizza is a square, is a round tomato a tomato? (A tom-what?)<n><n>### Response : Yes<n><n>### Explanaition : Round means a shape that it's been deformed in a circle, so to keep it simple and keep track of a tomato, when it's a shape that's a circle.<n><n>### Difficulty:Beginner<n>### Category:Algebra<n><n>### Created:Sep 2019<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Sam went to Paris where he ordered a blowfish at a sushi place.  Where was Sam? Choices:  A: books B: france C: fish market D: atlantic ocean E: cuba<n><n>### Response:		<n>Sam went to France<n><n>### Input:(The number on the roulette wheel  is a prime number,  what is the smallest prime number you could have picked to be the number on the roulette  wheel.<n><n>### Response<n>Answers are:<n>### Input:Which number, greater than or equal to, is a prime number.<n><n>### Answer:<n>5<n><n>### Input.  Sam goes to the store to buy some gum.  He buys 3 packs.  He pays $5 each pack.  The total is $15.  What is the cost for each pack?<n><n>### Response.<n>The cost for each pack= $5.<n><n>### Input, Sam and Tom went to the store and both had coupons.  Sam had 4  coupons and bought a  $15 pack of gum and Tom had 3 coupons and bought a $10 pack of gum.  What is the value of the coupons they have?<n><n>### Answer<n>The value of the coupons Sam and Tom has is $4 in total.<n><n>###<n>### Input, Sarah and Sarah were going out to dinner and they needed to buy a gift for each other.  Sarah's best friend and Sarah could afford $24 and  $18 and Sarah's best friend could afford 14 and $16.  How much can the two of them actually afford to buy each other a gift?<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where would there be many people sitting in chair and listening to religious speech? Choices:  A: auditorium B: office C: synagogue D: confession E: church<n><n>### Response:		<n>The correct answer is E. The wording of the question is ambiguous but the answer is nonetheless clear.<n><n>In general there is confusion between the words "chair" and "chairs" (although you could interpret the question as "for which of these would people be sitting on chairs"?), and there is also confusion between the word "sit" (a verb) and "seat" (a noun referring to a chair). I think the ambiguity was intentional.<n><n>The first question, "Where would there be many chairs?" is answered by A. A "synagogue" is a location in which many chairs would likely be found. If the question had simply said "What is a synagogue?", we can then say the correct answer is A, but it was not the intention of the question to ask about synagogues.<n><n>In the second question, the question is actually asking for the name of the place where there are many people sitting. The four places that are listed all contain the word "chair", and the correct answer is E, because it is the only place where in the question would the speaker describe "chairs" if talking about people sitting.<n><n>To make the question clearer, the question could have been written as "Where would there be people sitting with their backs to a chair/chairs?".

When someone is "loose," they are free to move about. When something is "loose," it is not fixed. A "lose" person or animal will have their limbs bound. And if something is "lose," it is missing. The "lose" that applies to sports is one that uses the rules to determine a winner who may play against "loose."<n><n>### Input<n><n>You are in a public place when you can't help but overhear a group of people talking about the difference between "loose" "lose" in front of some children. Choices:  A: weak B: fragile C: forceless D: regular E: flimsy<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer:<n><n>D. The correct answer is D.  Glass that is untreated but not super strong is a regular glass.  Super strong glass is stronger than regular glass.  Fragile glass is untreated glass that is weak and may break easily and is more easily damaged.  When glass shatters, it can no longer be considered as regular glass and becomes fragile.  Glass that can take force and is untreated, such as glass from windows, is not very strong and would be classified as forceless.<n><n>### Rationale:<n><n>To answer this question, we can look at the answer choices first. We can see all the answer choices are adjectives that describe various forms of glass.  Super strong will be a type of <n>glass. The answer choice can be determined to be fragile since fragile glass is glass that is weak, and it has the word fragile in it.  Glass that has been forceless is weaker than glass that has been super strong.  The next options is glass that has not been strengthed.  This answer can also be ruled as regular glass since regular glass is what has not been strengthened and is not super strong.  If super glass is the strongest grade of glass, the glass that is not super strong should be classified as fragile, which it is.<n><n>### Input : A box of cookies costs  $2.99 and there are 6 in a package. You want to give some to a friend. You only have dollar bills in your wallet. We notice that there is two parts $0.99 (6 cookies for $2.99) and another $0.99 since there is 6 cookies again. If you already had $1.50, you would be able to buy 2 of the 6 cookie boxes for a total of<n>12 cookies. You can then give the extra cookies as a thank you to your friend.<n><n><n>### Riddle:<n>

How might he go about ensuring his calculations are accurate? <n>  - A: review his calculations closely and use a calculator <n>  - B: make sure that the math equations are correct in the first place<n>  - C: do the calculations by hand instead of using a calculator<n>  - D: use a different formula to determine the correct answer <n>  - E: look up the information and check the results from multiple sources<n><n>### Response to Instructions:<n>If using a calculator to avoid being incorrect sometimes; the engineer would have to double check the math equations before doing the calculation and use a different formula to give an accurate results. In exactly 11 years he and his new wife will have a child that is 11 months old. If the man's wife was 25 years old, how old is the man?<n><n>- A: 31<n>- B: 30<n>- C: 21<n>- D: 25<n>- E: 28<n><n>### Response<n>- If the man was at least 31 years old his wife was under 25 years old.  Using this to solve, we can divide 25 by 11 and calculate approximately 2.28. As a result for 31 years subtract from 12 months we can estimate his wife to be 28 years old. When the couple will be having a baby in 11 years from now the woman must be at least 28 years. If the couple was under 21 to have children at their age they have to be married at least 30 years. If the man was at 31 years old and his wife was at least 25, he was at least 30 to have a child. So, the man was at least at 31 year old married to a woman under 25 is correct.<n><n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:If you were looking for a lemur where would you find it? Respond using a minimum of 60 words.<n><n>I was working on a research paper at school the other day. My teacher had given instructions that we were to keep our thoughts succinct as to make our points clear and unwavering. I sat down at the computer with pencil in hand and waited for the cursor to blink. I decided I would first write the outline and then transfer that onto the computer. That way I could be sure and concise in my writing. This helped because as I started to type out my sentences, the outline would give me a cue on what my next sentence would be. I was determined to get this assignment done, then I realized that I had lost interest. When the time came to turn in my paper for grading, I felt as though, as my teacher had said, my thoughts were not succinct enough and they were not clear enough. I realized that although my thinking may not have been what I had intended, that it was still good in the end, as a rough draft.<n>

We can’t go to the theater, bakery, refrigerator or the grocery store, because those are all physical spaces we would visit if we wanted to bake a cakes ourselves. Therefore, we would go to the oven since the question specifically mentions baking a cake.<n><n>### Input : If there was not a second person, how would you spend the evening? Choices :  A: Read B: Cook Dinner C: Watch tv E: Listen to music<n><n>### Response<n>Input: If you are the only person in the space the question asks about and are by yourself (that is, there is no second person) then it’s natural to say you would read a book. Otherwise, what would happen? You would, after all, spend the evening with another person. The other option might fit with answering the question to say you’d cook a meal—but that seems like it assumes there’s a second person there and that they want to eat.<n><n>### Output: The answer is in the last line.<n><n>## 📋 Worksheet:<n>1. You would either need to know how many whole numbers were lost, such as students who lost 5 points, students who lost 3 points, etc. You'll also need to know how many students lost partial points, such as a student who lost 6 points and a student who lost 8 points, as well as a student who lost no points, and a student who lost -1/2 of a point.<n><n>### Question.<n>- What do you get when you add four numbers in the prime number 19?<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What happens when someone is playing too aggressively? Choices:  A: get hungry B: laughter C: injury D: having fun E: feeling happy<n><n>### Response:		<n>[C# code](./AnswerCode.cs)
