Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Someone who is awake is likely to know what's going on because they are this? Choices:  A: alert B: deep sleep C: drink coffee D: open eyes E: conscious<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choices A and B are incorrect.  <n>Coffee does not necessarily need to be consumed in order to be considered conscious.<n>I had trouble coming up with a concrete definition for "awake" that did encompass all of the other choices.<n>It is difficult for me to explain this clearly enough to score full credit.  I could provide some justification for why the two choices A and B are incorrect, but I don't think the response would be considered thorough.

Choices:  A: lay eggs B: eat fruit C: wrestle D: compete with each other E: draw pictures<n><n>### Response:		<n>Human do not lay eggs.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>We can see from the question that human’s action in a race is to compete with each other. In “eat fruit”, we can see the opposite meaning of a race. So, the answer is “draw pictures”.<n>

Option A is the examination of the thing and Option B is staring into the mirror. Option C is going somewhere whereas Option D is to hear news and Option E is to watch a favorite tv show. Here the answer we chose to go somewhere was the right answer. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The sample needed to be pure, but the lab assistant got it what? Choices:  A: corrupt B: applied C: dirty D: contaminated E: fresh<n><n>### Response:		<n>Richard and Hurley’s ages combined are 46 years less for hurley’s age now. their combined ages 46 years from now would be 61 years old. That would be 105 years ago. 20 years ago hurley was 12, that means in 20 years Richard would be 64 and Hurley would be 22 in 20 years. So their combined ages 48 years from now would be Richard 82 and Hurley 36 in the future.<n><n>### Input : Input: Pablo’s mother agreed to pay him a cent for anything he read. He planned to save that money for any candy. Pablo always gets out books that are exactly a 150 pages long. He then went to the shop and spent in $16.75 in candy money and $3.25 in change. How much did he have to start with?<n><n>### Answer: Pablo was given a 150 page book and he read for a total of 12 books, he gets 1 cent for every page (not per book). When he saved the money from the books, Pablo kept 20 cents for every 150 pages (1 book), and he kept 2 cents for every 25 pages (pages not in a book or other factors) so he has a total of $14 in candy money and 39 cents in change. 39 cents times 16 books= $6.32, that is how many books he read. $14 + $6.32= $14.32<n><n>### Input<n>The group of six planned to buy a car for $1700, and they plan to share that cost equally. <n>At the car wash, the raise $500 and decide to raise the total cost by $500. Brad the original member of the car-pooling group decides not the participate in buying the car, how much more would each member have to pay?<n><n>### answer: Each member would have to pay another $10 each. $1700/6 = $283.<n><n>### The sample is contaminated<n><n><n><n><n>

This leaves $2.36 available.  Subtracting $2.36 from 95% of $2.40 is = $0.09

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is not a safe way to transport jewelry on vacation? Choices:  A: theatre B: fairgrounds C: friend's house D: show E: casino<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>E<n><n>## Solution:<n>```C# Sharp<n>using System;<n><n>namespace Ex5<n>{<n>    public class Age<n>    {<n>        public int First { get; set; }<n>        public int Second { get; set;  }<n><n>        public Age(int first, int second)<n>        {<n>            First = first;<n>            Second = second;<n>        }<n><n>        public int Minus()<n>        {<n>            int sum = Second - First;<n><n>            return sum;<n>        }<n>    }<n><n>    public class Read<n>    {<n>        private int _price;<n>        private int _pagesRead;<n>        public int Price { get; set; private void SetPrice(int price)<n>        {<n>             _price = price;<n>        }<n>        public int PagesRead { get; set;<n>        private void SetpagesRead(int pagesRead)<n>        {<n>          _pagesRead = pagesRead;<n>        }<n>     }<n>     }<n><n>    internal class Program<n>    {<n>        internal static void Main(string[] args)<n>        {<n>        int answer1 = 12;<n><n>        int age = 20;<n>        int currentAge = 20; <n>        int newAge = age + 1;<n><n>        if (newAge == 40)<n>        {<n><n>        int diff = newAge-currentAge;<n>        int ageMinus = diff.Minus();<n><n>        Console.WriteLine(answer1);<n><n>        }<n>        }<n>    internal static void Main2(string[] args) {<n>      int answer2 = 12; <n><n>        int price = 1;<n>  int pages=0;<n>      if (price == 1 && pages == 1)<n>      {<n><n>          int pagesRead=150;<n>          int costOfPages = pages.Minus();<n>      }<n>      else<n>      {<n>        int costOfPages = price.Minus();<n>        int priceAddPages = pages.Add(costOfPages);<n>    }<n>  ```<n><n>The program compares `price` and `pages`. `price` is 1 if the cost of the books are 1$ each. `pages` is 150 pages if the cost of each page is 2.5

He felt that the alternative might have results that were too what? Choices:  A: eternal B: religious C: unpredictable D: holy E: monastic<n><n>### Response:		<n>In 1993, the American Psychiatric Association removed homosexuality from the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual, an official reference for mental health, which, in doing so, removed homosexuality as a pathology.<n><n>This was a huge turnaround in their viewpoint 50 years earlier, when homosexuality was still identified as a mental disturbance. The American Psychological Association had been more ambivalent as recently as 1994, but the American Psychiatric association was more decisive than ever in 1993.<n><n>In 1973, the American Psychological Association concluded that homosexuality should not be a mental illness.  This decision was affirmed by the National Association of Social Workers in 1975.<n><n>### Notes:<n>This is one of those rare issues that crosses both social & biological topics.  This is an issue that crosses the boundaries of gender.  The human condition transcends all boundaries.<n><n>### <n><n>In this section, we will go through a tutorial on the use of the library to solve a classified problem and the way to submit your assignment.<n><n>1. Write the ```main.c``` program which will read ```n``` values from the keyboard and store them in an array ```x[n]```. <n>Your ```main.c``` should include the following:<n>```c<n>#include<stdio.h><n>int main()<n>{<n>  int x[10];         //array to store first n values<n>  int n;<n>  printf("Enter Number of elements you want");<n>  scanf("%d",&n);<n>  printf("Enter n numbers: ");<n>  for(int i=0;i<n;i++){<n>    scanf("%d", &x[i]);<n>  }<n>  int sum = 0;<n>  for (int i=0; i<n; i++){<n>    sum += x[i];<n>    }<n><n>  printf("Sum=%d",sum);<n><n>  <n><n>}<n>```<n><n>```<n>2. The code needs to compile and link with ```g++ main.c -o Program```<n><n>3. We accept assignments through TAs only using ```turnitin.tamu.edu```<n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:One way to relieve your hunger if you live near the coast is to do what? Choices:  A: grill B: go to market C: bring home fish D: eat hamburger E: make bread<n><n>### Response:		What is the function of the verb ‘grill’? Choices:  bring home fish, eat hamburger, make bread, go to market, relieve your hunger, eat fish<n><n>### Input Choices:  A set of 100 identical coins is chosen. Two coins are removed, each time without replacement. Let the value of the coins be represented by an integer. What is the next term in this sequence? Choices:  59, 53, 49, 35, 16, -16, -35, -59<n><n>### Response Choices:  22, 25, 28, 31, 34, 37, 40, 44, 47<n><n>- [](https://leetcode.com/problems/find-the-duplicate-element/)

Choices:  A: verdict B: judging C: responsibility D: evaluating E: prejudice<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is the first one.<n><n>### Input 4:Mitch and Katelyn are going on a road trip together to meet up with their friends.  Mitch’s vehicle can hold 6 bags total, and each bag weighs 10 lbs. Katelyn’s vehicle can hold a total of 8 bags, and each bag weights 9 lbs. How many bags can fit in each vehicle? Choices:  a: 6 c: none b: 4 d: 2<n><n>### Response 4: The correct answer is option D.<n><n>### Question 1:How do you solve for the unknown in 4x + 11 = 2x + 2?<n><n>### Answer 1: To solve we could start by cross multiplying 4x with the 2x + 11. Then we would get an equation, 4x = 21 - x. From here you divide both sides by 4 to get the last equation. x/4 = 1/4 and X=25<n><n>### Question #2 :How do you multiply two integers? How do you simplify?<n><n>### 10x is a 10 multiplied by x with no division or exponents. To multiply x by10 multiply the number by 10.<n><n>### 9 x 3 is nine times threeto multiply, put the numbers together and put an X and a 1 for the other number.<n><n>### To convert decimal to a fraction, start with the decimal point and move one digit to the left.<n><n>### Then divide the numbers. When dividing by a decimal, move the decimal point that many spaces and divide.<n><n>### The answer would be 3/4<n><n>### Question: Convert from degrees Farenheit to Celsius.<n><n>### Convert from degrees Celsius to degrees Farenheit.<n><n>### In order to change from Farenheit to Celcius, we take the degree Farenheit-40 and multiply it by 5 to get the degree Celcius.<n><n>##  06 📦🚑 - 🇨🇺 Coding Chat 🤯#3 <n>### Coding Challenge<n>### Input:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The lady was doing a one man show of her tell story, when the show began she did what? Choices:  A: persuade B: slept C: take center stage D: challenge E: speak clearly<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n><n>### Reason:<n><n>1. One man show = lady was going to be performing the story on her own.<n>2. Persuade is to convince someone that something is right<n><n>### The Story:Once upon a time when there were no stores on Main Street there was a rich man in town who loved to buy all the goods. As a result, the villagers left him alone for most of the week. He felt lonely and missed the social aspects of townspeople. So he went to the blacksmith and challenged him to stay in town and perform a one-man show in front of the whole town. The blacksmith and his family began to enjoy the weekly performances and the blacksmith quickly became a part of the community.<n><n>### Input<n>Another time, when the townspeople were getting hungry for a good meal and needed to buy groceries, the blacksmith stepped in and persuaded them to eat at the tavern for a chance to win a prize. The townspeople all decided to have dinner for free if they would just buy groceries.<n><n>### The Solution:<n>The lady went to perform her show and persuaded all the townspeople to listen to her story.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>Persuade is going to be used in this situation to convince the townspeople to join her for a story and to buy groceries.

If we cannot purchase all three, which item should we buy?<n><n>### Answer<n>You should buy the roof for the church since that is the cheapest choice among all.<n>

A: B C: D<n><n>### Instructions:Write a loop that iterates through your list of data values, adding them to your array.  Each individual value should be added as a new element.<n><n>### Example Input: 35<n><n>### Example Output: 35<n>```javascript<n>function incrementArray(num, array) {<n>  for (let x = 0; x < num; x++) {<n>    array.push(x);<n>  }<n>  return array;<n>}<n>incrementArray (5, [0]);<n>```<n><n>### Example:Input:Which of the following is NOT a correct solution?<n>```javascript<n>const increment = (numArray, myArr) => {<n>  for (index = 0; index < myArr.length; index++) {<n>    myArr[index]++;<n>  }<n>  for (index in myArr) {<n>    console.log(myArr[index]);<n>  }<n>  console.log(document.heading);<n>}<n>increment()<n>```<n><n>## Exam <n>* <n>

If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:A yard is made up of what? Choices:  A: city B: michigan C: three feet D: subdivision E: three arm span<n><n>### Response:		E<n><n>### A:1 B: 1 C: 3 D: 3 E: 1 Yards is used to describe large area of land. Yards are used for measuring the width and length of land and buildings. <n>

Therefore, if the choice is not available, it is the option D.<n>### Instruction : Write a program that will calculate the total area of any shape that you draw.<n><n>### Input : If a rectangle shape is drawn, calculate the area. If a triangle is drawn, calculate the perimeter.<n><n>### Response : Write pseudo code<n><n>### Note:<n>Each response should not be more than 100 words per program, and all should be done in the same document with the programs<n><n>### Name:<n>Hoai Pham<n><n>### Class:<n>CS 265 - Programming with Java Lab 1<n><n>### Submission Name:<n>AreaOfShape<n><n>### Assignment: 1<n><n>## Instruction: Draw one shape and determine its area or perimeter.<n>## Input: A user will draw a shape, <n><n>### Demostration:<n>  Input: The user draws a rectangle. Determine the area.<n><n>### Output: Draw a 3x5 rectangle. The area is 15 sq/m.<n><n>## Pseudo Code :<n>1. Create a method in the main class, name it drawShape().<n>2. DrawShape() accepts two parameters of type String, x1 and y1. These parameters stand for the coordinates of the coordinates of the upper-left corner of the shape. For example, a square, drawn in the coordinate (1,2), means that the upper-left corner is located at (1,2). <n>3. After a user draws a square, a user's area of rectangle has to be computed. The area is<n>a rectangles is the following: width x height. In a case where a user draws a rectangle of a shape width x height = 3; 4,  answer = 3 x 4 = 12. <n>4. In the end, the method drawShapes(), tells a user his  perimeter.<n><n><n><n>### Note : Programming should work on two different devices, including Windows laptop and Macbook. <n>

Write a R function named `read_number` which takes a character string and a type parameter. The type parameter may be one of the letters in the following table.<n><n>When the function is called with an empty string as the input character string, the function should return a zero of the specified type.<n><n>If the type parameter is not present, `integer` should be assumed.<n><n>To test the function, run the following with R installed. After typing `library(readr)` run `dput(read_number("", "integer"))` and confirm the output is 0.<n><n>To run the function `read_number` in RStudio, press _Run_ to run the function.<n><n>### Parameters<n>- type: Must either be one of "double", "integer" or an empty (null) string. Null string indicates "doubles". All other types are integer. This type is always a non-null string, so if type is not specified, "integer" is assumed.<n>- character string: Input from user, or the first argument to the function call if the `read_number` function is called with no arguments.<n>- default value: 0<n><n>### Example<n>In this example, read_number("", "double") returns 0 and read_number("", "") returns '`.`'.<n><n>- `read_number("", "")`<n>- `read_Number("", "double")`<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The clothing was extremely expensive compared to other places, where was it likely purchased? Choices:  A: cinema hall B: mall C: department store D: closet E: shop<n><n>### Response:		<n>In the case of the first line, we are given information on both Hurley and Richard.  Our task is to add together their total age now and also add 40 to that.  Since Hurley is 16, we can solve for Richard as they are the same age difference (in 40 years):<n><n>    let totalAge = (Hurley'sAge + Richard'sAge) + 40;<n><n>The next example is a very nice example to use to practice your skills.  We know there are 6 friends in total and our goal is to calculate what each friends needs to pay on their own for the car.  It is the same formula as the other one.<n><n>    let totalCost = 1700 - (500 * 2);<n>    <n>    let remaining = 1702 / friendsCount;<n>    <n><n>We can simplify it using what is called "greater than/equal to" or ">=".<n>    let remaining = (totalCost >= 500) / friendsCount;<n><n>We simply plug in the friendsCount in to solve.  There's a few ways to do this.  You could plug each number in.  Or you could use the mod and divide functions.  Let's think about what it means when Hurley is 19.  We could break it down:<n><n>    let numberOfYears = 20;<n>    let remainder = totalAge ~ (friendsCount - 1);<n>    <n>    remainder = totalAge-40 ~ friendsCount;<n>    19 ~ 3 = 7<n>    remainder = total(7) ~ 3;<n>    remainder = totalDivide(7 ~ 3);<n>    remainder = 1 ~ 3;<n>    1 ~ 3 = 4<n>    remainder = totalSubtract(first-4) ~ 3; <n>    <n>Note: This can be more messy or less messy based on how you format. I am usually more messy about it. <n><n>Lastly, the answer to number 4 is A. <n>

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:When you experience boredom, what can you do on television? Choices:  A: watch film B: play cards C: play chess D: read news papers E: surf net<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>> ```python<n>> b = input('when you experience boredom what can you do on tv?')<n>> response = "B"<n>> ```<n><n>## Task:<n><n>### Instructions:You and your friends recently decided to go to a restaurant for lunch. There were six of you total, and you each left the restaurant and got separate meals from the food truck two cities away.<n><n>### You are now trying to figure out just how much each of you paid for your food. Unfortunately, you forgot to write down the cost of each meal when you purchased it, and one of your friends did not pay her own bill at all and is now threatening to ruin any progress you made by talking about lunch all day.<n><n>### To save everybody's patience, what two numbers can you calculate to determine how much each person paid at the food truck? (Hint: the answer will involve the two letters B and D.)<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>```python<n>import math<n><n>def main():<n>    b = 4 # number of people to figure out bill<n>    d = 10 # number for denominator<n>    p = "bill" # variable for calculating bill<n><n>    nbill = 0 # no of bills<n>    for i in range(0,b):<n>        p = float(int(input("How much did you pay for your meal? type " + str(i) + " in the below")))<n>        nbill = nbill + p<n><n><n>    den = int(0 / float(d) + 1)<n><n>    print(b) - den<n>    res = nbill % den <n><n><n><n>if __name__ == '__main__':<n>    main() <n>```<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>How much did you pay your meal?<n>type 1<n><n>How much did you pa your meal?<n>Type 2<n><n><n>How much did your pay meal?<n>Type3<n><n>```<n>

What is the best way to make dinner with the supplies in the kitchen, and with the restrictions in mind?<n><n>### Response - Option A:  There are 2 burners, 1 oven; so each person cook 1 of the 2 burners and 1 of the 1 ovens.<n><n>Input: A farmer is trying to divide up his land so the two sides will trade evenly at a sale in three years.  He wants to divide up his land in the following manner:  On the first side, he divided the land into three equal pieces.  On the second side, he divided the largest piece into twelve equal parts and the smallest piece into 29 equal parts.  He wants the two sides to consist of about the same number of acres.  The two sides together have 1224 acres altogether.  What is the greatest amount of acres that the two sides can consist of together if they are the same in number of acres?<n><n>### Answer: 1200<n><n>### Direction: <n><n>### Instructio:  <n>You can use each of your three ratios once.  You cannot replace them later.  The two ratios must be different.  Use the two ratios below to create three ratios total. <n><n>### Response-Option A<n><n>% 6.5/8 - 27/16  <n>% 0.24/4.4 - 0.15   <n>% 10.1/8  <n><n>### Instuction: <n>What is the sum of the two ratios and what is the average ratio of the sum? <n><n>### Answer - Option A<n><n>### Instrumention:<n><n>### What? <n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>Write a response that appropriately answers the task.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Rumors of roving bands of monsters killing people could lead to what? Choices:  A: panic B: getting in trouble C: mass hysteria D: go to prison E: murder<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n><n>### Input<n><n>The difference in ages between Richard  and  Hurley   is 20.  If  Hurley  is 14  years  old,  what  are their combined  ages 40 years  from  now?<n><n>```python<n>ageDifference = 20<n>currentAge = 14<n>ageInYears = int(ageDifference) + 40<n>sum = currentAge + ageInYears<n>print("Your combined ages:", sum)<n>```<n><n>### Output:<n>Your combined ages: 54<n><n><n>### Instructions<n>- Answer the following multiple choice question based on the data that you enter. Use the data you enter in your own Python program.<n>- Display results to a console window by adding statements like the one illustrated below<n><n><n>### Response<n><n><n>### Output<n>Your combined ages:<n><n>1. 128<n>2. 12<n>3. 49<n><n>Input<n><n>A group of six friends planned  to  buy a car.  The  cost of the car  is  $1700  and  they  plan to  share the cost equally.  They had a car washing  to  help raise  funds,  which  would  be  taken  out of the total cost   The remaining cost  would  be  split  between the six friends.  At the car wash. they  earn $50   However, Brad  decided not to join  in  the purchase of  the car.  How much  more does  each friend have  to  pay now  that  Brad  isn  t  participating<n><n>```python<n>friends = 6<n>carCost = 1700<n><n>carWashIncome = 500<n><n>totalCostOfCar = friends * carCost + carWashIncome<n><n>for friendsLeft in range (0, friends):<n>    friendsToBeInvested = totalCostOfCar - carsWashIncome<n>    print(f"Amount each friend has to pay: $ {friendsToBeInvested}")<n><n>```<n><n>

If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Where could you find an armchair that is used by only a few people? Choices:  A: doctor's office B: hospital C: apartment D: study E: furniture store<n><n>### Response:		<n>C)<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the second multiple choice question.<n>Where could you find an umbrella that is used by only one person?<n><n>C)<n><n>1. It has to be used by only one person, so it would be unlikely to be found in an office, furniture store, or hospital, where multiple people share a common resource. Since the umbrella would be owned/used by only one person, it would likely be at their home.<n><n>2. It has to be one that is used by "only one" person, so it would seem unlikely that it would be at an apartment building or study, because multiple people share those spaces.<n><n>3. A doctor's office or hospital are unlikely places at which to find an umberella since there are many different patients who come in and use the doctor's office or medical spaces. So it would seem like an umberella found in one office building or medical space would be used by many people each time.<n><n>4. At a furniture store, there would be many umberellas that were available for sale, so it would seem that the one that would be left over was likely purchased for multiple individuals. There is a likelyhood that umberallas at an office building or study would be shared between multiple people each time.<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What will all the differences equal? Choices:  A: sum B: likeness C: alike D: sameness E: similarity<n><n>### Response:		<n>A difference is defined to be the mathematical difference between the two numbers it represents. This can be thought of as the number that we subtract in order to make the two numbers equal and opposite. If we take this number, we have what is referred to as the absolute difference between the two numbers. The absolute difference is always a positive number.<n><n>The sum is defined to be the addition of two or more numbers together. The sum is also referred to as an additive property, since it is what we use in addition in order to compute it. The sum of two or more numbers can be thought of as their combined value, where no matter where the numbers start or end, they will always come together to form what is called an additive set.<n><n>Since the sum of two numbers is the value of adding them together, these two values will always be different. When they are different, the sum is what we have when adding two or more numbers. Thus, when the answer is a sum, the numbers were taken and then added together.<n><n>When we do addition, the sum can be either greater or less than the two numbers used together in order to form the addition. This is because any number or numbers can be used to form addition. For many, the sum will always be less than the two numbers. The two numbers are added to form the addition, and the sum is the final answer of the total that was used.<n><n>The sum of the numbers that are added to form an addition can always be the same as the addition formed if these numbers are all exactly equal.  However, in most cases, the sum will be much larger than or less than the actual addition. In this case, the difference is the final result of the addition. The difference is the result of subtraction.<n><n>The Likeness of two numbers is sometimes referred to as the difference between the sum of two or more other numbers. For example, the total number of items bought on an item sale is $4845 and there were two items sold at half price. The total of the sale is $4890. Thus, the number that was subtracted in order to make the total the same is $490. This is what is called the likeness of the number that was used.<n>This is different from the Sum and the Difference.<n><n>The Sameness of two numbers is what happens when two numbers are equal. For example, it can also be described as

Lakes can be very deep (i.e deep bodies of water such as oceans), however the water is very fresh and saline levels are high. This is not shallow water, so the answer is swimming pools.

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The explorers found a central passage, much to their delight it led straight to the ancient buried what? Choices:  A: public building B: tomb C: arena D: large building E: treasure<n><n>### Response:		<n>Choose E, B<n><n><n>Choose A<n><n>### Challenge:<n>```python<n>def main():<n>    a, b, c, d, e = 0<n>    while True:<n>        try:<n>            x=int(input("Enter age: "))<n>            a=x<n>            break<n>        except KeyError:<n>            print("Please enter an Age!")<n>            continue<n>    while True: <n>        try:<n>               x=int(input(name+": "))<n>               b=x<n>               break<n>        except Keyerror:<n>            print(name+": Please enter an Age!")    <n>            continue<n>    total = a+b<n>    if total > 600:<n>        c = total+31<n>    c2 = c+29<n>    if c2 > 40:<n>        d = (c2-29)+29<n>    d2 = d+29<n>    print('How many books did Pablo read '+name+'?')<n>    if d2+a*3 > 1110:<n>        e=d2+a*3-1110<n>    while True :<n>        try:<n>        input("Hit Enter to answer\n")<n>        break<n>        except:<n>        print("Error")<n>    if e==11:<n>        print(answer)<n>        break<n>        <n>```<n><n>### Challenge Accepted:

Choices:  A: music shop B: music store C: jug band D: united states E: among nice people<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are multiple ways this question could be answered. <n><n>B: Music store<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a script that performs the following.<n><n>Write a function called showBanjoHistory() that prints on the screen the history of the banjo’s use. <n><n>Input/Parameters:<n><n>`No arguments`<n><n>Returned Value:<n><n>`No Value return`<n><n>### Expected outputs:<n><n>```shell<n>music store<n>```<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Input:<n><n>```bash<n>#!/bin/bash<n><n>banjoHistory()<n>{<n>    local myhistory=''<n><n>    for i in {1..20};<n>    do<n>        myhistory+="<n>            music store<n>            "<n>    done<n><n>    echo $myhistory<n>}<n>```<n><n>## How to Submit a Script:<n><n>Submit a zip file that contains all of the following:<n><n>1. Name of your project<n>2. Scripts and instructions<n>3. Instructions.txt with the instruction and the expected answer<n>

The Pentagon is a 5 sided shape.<n><n>### Intructions:  The following statements are true!<n>Input: The only square inside a pentagon is the central side.<n><n>Input: A pentagon is a 5-sided shape.<n><n>[Answer](images_55/1.png)<n>[Answer](images/1.png)

Use your graphing calculator for #14.<n><n>### Solution<n>Input:<n><n>10. An equation in vertex form for an ellipse is written as:<n><n>aX² + bXy + cy² + dx + ay = 0<n><n>Let a, b, c, d, and E represent variables for the following equations:<n><n>aX + bY = 0 <n><n>ax + y = 0 <n>Ax² + bXy = 0<n><n>- Ax² + bXy < aX + bY<n>(−1)(aX + bY) > −(aX² + bY)<n><n>11. What is the length of the diameter of a circle with radius given by r(t)?<n><n>12. What is the distance across a circle where x=r(0)?<n><n>13. If r, x, and h are all in a circle that has radius a, what is r²?<n><n>14. For what values of x will the line through the point (−10, −2) and (4,2) have an equation of the form x+y =−a. (Note that there might not be any values of x.)<n><n>### Exercises<n><n>```<n>15-16. Find the equation of the ellipse with the given parameters.<n><n>Ellipse Parameters: (7,2), (2,3), 18<n>```<n>### Explanations<n><n>Input:<n><n>### Instructor:Answer questions 10 – 16 from your review shee. Use your graphing calcu-lator for #14<n><n>### Solution:<n>Input:<n>Ax + by = 0<n>Output:<n>ax + by<ax² + bx<n><n>Output:<n>ax^2 + bx = ax² + a*b<n><n>Input

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:Learning languages is difficult.  Even in a full immersion environment you're likely to make mistakes, mistakes will cause misinterpretation, which will be uncomfortable, which will cause what?, Choices:  A: better communication B: overthinking C: frustration D: misunderstandings E: headaches<n><n>### Response:		<n>**E:**<n><n>### Instructions:<n>For each question, provide two different pieces of supporting evidence that support your answer. Each of these supporting evidences should be statements and not a question.<n><n>## 1. <n>**E:** Communication is only possible when at least two parties are involved. You can’t understand someone if you don’t speak the same language they do. Even if you take away the language difference, communication can be challenging because a single mis-match in tone, eye contact or hand gesturing can derail a conversation and cause unnecessary frustration. <n><n>## 2.<n>#### Answer:<n>**B:**<n><n>#### Supporting evidence:<n>Language skills are the single largest contributor to the quality of a tourist experience. The better the language skills, the less likely a tourist is to experience communication problems, such as mis-understandings, mis-interpretation, frustration with locals, or headaches from over-thinking or miscommunications. For example, in some countries, "hello" is used as a greeting during conversations such as when being served at the counter of a hotel restaurant. Some tourists use the same word to greet a shopkeeper, which may result in the shopkeeper not responding. A tourist could have been greeted with "hello", responded to the greeting, and continued to speak to a shopkeeper before realizing he/she didn’t speak English.<n><n>#### Supporting data:<n>Language proficiency has become a significant factor in determining which cities are attractive to tourists. A recent survey showed that Spanish speaking visitors to a location are more likely to experience positive service and positive impressions of its people than visiting American tourists who don’t communicate with those they engage with in their everyday lives. <n>

Choices:<n>> A: reach tentative<n>> agreement<n>> B: suicide<n>> C: examine thing<n>> D: commit murder<n>> E: stay in bed.<n><n>The sentence "They decided to hash out thing over drink" means "They decided to talk things out over drinks". The "things" were the ones that made them disagree in the first place. The choices A-C refer to the "things" that made them disagree. Hence, A-D are wrong. The remaining choice (E) is wrong, because the word "stay in bed" modifies "drinks", and drinks don't involve one or other of participants staying in bed.<n><n>### Input : Write a sentence that uses the expression: "the cat's got your tongue".<n><n>### Demands:The expression, used as a metaphor, implies the speaker is surprised or puzzled by their response to something they said, or the lack of anything a speaker says in reply.<n><n>### Response : "The cat's got your" - correct<n><n>## Input : Write a sentence using the expression, "out of the frying pan, into the fire".<n><n>## Demonstration : The phrase serves as a euphemism for getting into an unpleasant situation.<n><n>## Response: Sentence : "Having been fired out of the frying" - incorrect<n><n>## Answer : Sentence :"Out of the frying pot, into the fire." - correct<n><n>## Demands for Input :<n><n>### Demand 1: "the frying pan" - correct<n><n>The phrase "out of the frieding pan, into the frying fire" refers to an un

Choices:  A: good health B: finger C: meat D: body E: own family<n><n>### Response:		<n>In this article, the question was ‘How many pages are there in a Harry Potter series?’. As for my answer, ‘The Harry Potter series totals nearly 6,000 printed pages: books 1-7, which were all released in the years [2002-2009], contain more than 3,300 pages, while books and 8 and 9, both released in 2011, comprise 2,400. (The number-crunchers at Scholastic had to factor in the fact that Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows, the seventh and final installment, was split into two parts.) A 2015 study found that, over all, an average chapter in a Harry Potter novel is about nine pages long and about 810 words long. Each volume, then, likely features at least 398, and possibly as many as 428, pages per book’ (https://www.businessinsider.com/pages-in-harry-potter-books-2013-11).’<n><n><n>Input: If Harper had a party with the theme “Heroes” and served pizza and salad for $10 per person, how much would it cost to have two parties with the same theme?<n><n><n>Input: Each of 8th grade students will take 3 standardized tests next month in reading, writing, and math. Choices:  A: kitchen cupboard B: pantry C: grocery store D: pantry E: refrigerator<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Input 1:<n>Let’s say<n>that there are sixteen people, so the cost for one person is 1.<n><n>### Input N:<n>if N is 20,<n>the lowest number you can have is 120.<n><n>### Answer<n><n>The value of N is the total amount of money and the value of i is the number of people. The sum of money between 1 to N is N. Therefore, there are a total N(N+1)/2 money. Each person's value is 1/N.<n>```<n>The total cost is 1 × 1/N. <n>```<n><n><n>### Inputs:<n><n>### Response 1:<n><n>### Example 1:<n><n>```python<n>Input:A man has 12 apples and decides to cut them into 4 pieces. He sells each piece at $0.30 and finds himself being left with no remainder. What is the amount he made from selling the apples?<n>```<n><n>### Example2:<n><n><n>```python<n>A man owns a restaurant and charges $2 per piece of cake. If one customer orders 4 pieces, will the cake holder get the cake?<n>```<n><n><n><n>### Response2:<n><n>### 1. Input: The difference in ages of two people is 16. A different train left Station A the next day and traveled to Station B. If the trains traveled at an average of 300 miles per hour and they had the same starting time, in how many hours before the trains arrived at their destination was it Wednesday?<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>```python<n>a = 37<n>b = 30<n><n>a-b = 7 #difference in age<n><n><n>100 * 5 = 500 #5x10% = 10<n><n>100-50 = 50<n><n>50-50 =0<n>

It is logical to assume the person would find some electric fans and then the person would know where to place the fans. It is unlikely that the person would simply purchase an electric fan in a store and take it home. <n><n>### Input<n>If you divide something into 2, and the first person gets 11/3 what does the second person get?<n><n>### Response  <n>If you divide 36 into two, then you would get 18. The first person would receive 3/8 of the 36, which is 11/8. Then the second person would receive (3/8) * 18, which would be 11/8 * 18 = 51/8.<n><n>### Input  <n>If you divide something in half, the person who receives half of the whole thing also receives an equal amount of what is left. <n><n>## Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question<n>## Demonstration: <n>Input: <n><n>## Response:

Why are Brad’s expenses more than the remaining  expenses?<n>3. How much money is left after the garage, the video game store and the candy was purchased? Answer: cents)

His grandparents are 58 and his parents are 30. What time will his parents be born in 28 years from now?<n><n>### Answer:  The answer will be 38 years old.<n><n>### How do I do this? <n>![](/img/In-Class/in_class4.png)<n><n>### If the number is a multiple of 8 divide 8 from the number then the result will be a multiple of 8, if not just subtract each time until you get a multiple of 8 then  subtract 8<n><n>![](/img/screenshot11.png)<n><n><n>### How you do this?   What is the rule?  125 - 8 = 117    <n>The rule is ** 125-8 divided by 8 = 12 which is the multiple of 8**<n><n>Therefore the answer is zero since

However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4. Choices:  A: washing machine B: space shuttle C: blender D: disneyland E: surface of earth<n><n>### Response:		<n>We can use the `if` condition to check if the user input is equal to `E: surface of earth`. If the user input is equal `E: surface of the earth` we can print "Yes".<n>The other choices can be stored in a string, since each choice have 1 character. For example, if `B.Space shuttle`, is equal to `B`, the user need to print "No".<n><n>`if` condition:<n><n>```python<n>if choice == 'E: surface of earth':<n>```<n><n>`else` condition:<n><n>`elseif` condition:<n>	<n>`for` and `while` condition:<n><n>Note:<n><n>	<n>			<n>				<n><n>#### Solution:<n><n>		<n>	<div id = 'content'></div><n>	<script><n>		var myInput = prompt("What appliance uses water &amp; soap? Choices: A : washing machine B : space shuttle C : blender D : disneyland E : surface of earth", "");<n><n>		if(myInput === "E: surface of earth"){<n>			document.getElementById("content").innerHTML = "Yes."<n>		}else{<n>			var ans = "";<n>			var space = "";<n>		<n>		for (i = 0; i <= myInput.length; i++){<n>				ans += space;<n>				space = " ";<n>				for (let a = 0; a < myInput.length; a++){<n>			<n><n><n>				}<n>			}<n><n>			document<n>			.getElementById("content").<n>			innerHTML = ans<n>		}<n><n><n>		</script><n>		<n><n><n>#### Test Cases:<n><n>    [<n>		"E: surface of earth",<n>		"space shuttle",<n>		"A: washing machine",<n>		"d",<n>		"",<n>		"B: space shuttle",<n>    ]<n><n><n>### Demand:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Solution:<n><n>	<div id='content'></div>	<n>	<script>	<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:The whole family was playing cards, they were full of joy and what? This question was answered with a mathematical formula.<n>### Output: The answer to the question:<n><n>### Explanation: <n>The teacher has seven students and every student has five different questions and one of the students does not have a computer, that student will give away 6 questions. <n><n>We add 5 for the rest of the students, 6 for every student, and 1 for the student without a computer adding 7 times. We take 5 from the total and the answer is: 9, which is the number of possible combinations.<n>A formula for getting the number of possible combinations is:<n>((5x7 – 1)/5)<n><n>The answer to the question would be B because (5x7 – 6)/5 = 9.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>### What was the question?<n><n>### How do you answer this question?<n><n>## What is the answer?<n><n>### Expected Output <n>## Which statement is correct?<n><n>## What will the output be if the user enters a wrong answer?<n><n>## What statement is true about the output?<n><n>### Given:<n>A father is 24 years old. His son will be 60% of his age 15 years from now. The man's son will be 15 years old in 15 years. How old will he be in 8 years?<n><n>### Solution:<n>This is a situation is that someone’s age is 24. That means he is sixteen years old.<n>The man’s son will be 6 times 16 years old. That means his son will be 96 years old.<n>The son will be 16 years old in 16 years. Sixteen years from now is actually 13 years ago. So the man’s son will 32 ( 16 times

Choices: A: call police B: ask for directions C: walk to friend’s house D: buy a new bicycle E: cry for help<n>### Reasonings/Answer:<n>Calling the police is certainly the course of action to take if someone's bicycle gets stolen, while buying a new bicycle is the only choice that does not work in the context of losing one's bike.<n><n>### Problem 3:<n>Rebecca can play on the jungle gym for 12 minutes more than Dina can. Choices:  A: confusion B: complications C: riot D: arrest E: protests<n><n>### Response:		I was able to search through many search engines that would give me a list of synonyms that might help me as I'm researching. The ones that might also fit the bill are confusion, complications, riot, and arrest. That still does not tell me for sure. In the dictionary, civil action is defined as the action of taking someone to court if they have committed a crime or injustice. It is almost synonymous with the word sue. You can't call someone to court and have them arrested on a civil issue. It would be a criminal offense. When you search for things that might be synonymous for arrest, you come up with other words like detain, stop, hold, and apprehend. These only work when I am trying to find when the legal system is taking control of someone, so that they can question them or force them to answer a certain question. None of these apply though because the legal system only gets them in that situation or control because of an investigation that has already happened. It doesn't work like that when I am civil. I have an issue and I want to talk to the person and understand what it is. The legal system isn't even involved until it is decided that I am actually in the right. This doesn't happen until they look at everything to see if the action I took was a civil or a criminal action. I'm saying that I'm wrong when you think that I might take it to court. We can't have a civil action if I think that the lawyer might not be able to win. They have to agree that there is a civil issue, and that my lawyer knows the correct way to make a case out of it. When they decide that there is, my lawyer can make a case of it. This doesn't mean that there is a civil action, but it does mean that I might take what has already happened to the court and it will be considered an argument that is valid. All we are saying is that there is a reasonable argument on my side. The lawyer would be looking to see if it is too outrageous to be thought about. It doesn't matter too much about civil and criminal if everything is made up of a legal dispute. We can ask questions that are reasonable, and then we can use them to talk about how to prevent the criminal from happening. This is what the courts would look to when they wanted to decide if what we were doing was ok with the

How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. Choices:  A: drill B: learn C: require obedience D: understand E: spoon<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>[Click on the Run button above to run the script then check the output.](https://drive.google.com/file/d/14YXUUJ6C_p-3mHcK1jcw3Gc-CGE_46Bm/view?usp=sharing)<n><n># How many digits does the following binary sequence contain?<n><n>11110011<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Write a script that takes in a sequence of binary digits. Check for the number of digits. For example, "1101" has 4 digits, "111101" contains 12 digits, and so on. The above example contains only 8 digits. It can be expressed as "111111", "1111", etc. but 11110 = 8101 as base 2.  <n><n>### Solution:<n><n>Check for 1's and 0's only, there can be no empty space. A base 2 number is not 2 digits long. Example 1111 always equal to 1, no matter what base you have. So, in this case we have 1 digit, and the sequence goes on. "10" is still 1 digit.<n><n>## Requirements<n><n>[Click here to see the requirements.](Requirements.md)<n><n>[Click here for the solution.](./solutions.md)<n><n># 4. 5.<n><n># 4th week summary<n><n>![5th day weekly progress.jpeg](./5thDay.png)<n><n>| Date    | Problem | Time |<n>------- | ------- | -:-- |<n>[4.4](./problems/fourthweek4.md)        | 3.2             | 01:54:09.539 |<n>[4.5](./problems/4.5.md)   | 4              | 00:12:14.591 |<n>[4.6](./problems/6.md)        |          |  00:15:07.051 |<n>

Or locked.” This is because it has not yet been mentioned that the door was closed.<n><n>### Response<n>I have left a note on the door as follows, “I really need them (glasses) to see everything clearly. I would then ask him which type of glasses would he like to buy.<n><n>### Final response:<n>I am looking for a good glasses, what do they mean? When can I buy it? Write a correct response to the request.<n><n>[A](https://www.w3schools.com/cssref/pr_text_font-size.asp) <u>font-size</u>( <i>size of text in pixels</i> )</br><n>If you want to change the font size in a CSS rule: </br><n><n>```css<n>body{<n>font-size:16px;<n>}<n>```<n><n>### Instuctions: Display a prompt in a popup window.<n><n><n>In this template, you are provided with some CSS and HTML that will be inserted into a web page. Make copy of this file.**<n><n>>**Step2. Open up index.html and insert your own HTML code.**<n><n>```Html<n><!DOCTYPE html><n><html lang="en"><n><head><n>  <meta charset="UTF-8" /><n>  <meta http-equiv="X-UA-Compatible" content="IE=edge" /><n>  <title>Document</title><n>  <style><n> .foo{<n>  width:100px;<n>  height:100px<n>  }<n>  </style><n></head><n><body><n>  <div class="foo"></div><n></body><n></

Input must be identical to above except different choice is provided.<n><n>Answer: The same. (C)<n><n>### Hint:You will need to use if/else statement to determine which option was chosen. Diff= 5-1=4<n>2.  2*2 = 4<n>3.  Answer: 1<n><n>### Instructiom<n>How much candy does Pablo need to buy with $5 if books he always checks out are 150 pages long?<n><n>### Instuction Answer 1:<n>1.  M=P*Q<n>2.  64 =5* P<n>3.  Answer : 5<n><n>### Diomonstration 1:<n>1A. P=64-5<n>2A. p=63  <n><n>3A. Q=49  <n><n>4A. p*Q=2720<n><n>### Instution Answer 2:<n><n>1.     p = 5<n>2.    P= 10<n>3. Choices: A: the netherlands B: scotland C: spain D: egypt E: norway<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>```python <n>#function to find the answer of a question<n>def findT(a,b):<n>    a = a.lower()<n>    b = b.lower()<n>    if(a == 'egypt' or a =='the netherlands' or a == 'egypt'): <n>        return 0<n>    elif(b =='spain' or b == 'the netherlands'  or b == 'egypt'): return 0<n>    else:<n>        return 1<n>```<n>### Demostaration1 :<n><n>```python<n>a = 'egypt'<n>b = 'norway'<n>if(findT(a,b) == 0):<n>    print('answer = 1')<n>else:<n>    print('answer= 0')<n>a = 'the netherlands '<n>b = 'egypt' <n>if(findT({w).lower().lower() == 0):<n>print('answer=1')<n>else: <n>print('answer= 0'<n>```<n><n>### Demstraion 2:<n><n>```python #Function for 1<n>def findT(w,e):<n>    a = w.lower()<n>    e.lower()<n>    return<n>```<n>```python<n>a="egypt"<n>b="norway"<n>if(findT('egypt, norway','egypt ')):<n>print("answer = 0")<n>else:<n>print("answer =1")<n>```<n>### Exercise:<n><n>```python import random<n>input=''<n>my_input ="New York is the most populous city in America."<n>my_input.rsearch<n>my_input.replace("populous","populative")<n>print("my_input",my_input)<n>def findT(finder

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. They had a car wash to help raise funds, which would be taken out of the total cost. The remaining cost would be split between the six friends. At the car wash, they earn $500. However, Brad decided not to join in the purchase of the car. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What is a fast but expensive way to send small cargo? Choices:  A: airplane B: ship's hold C: boat D: truck E: train<n><n>### Response:		Airplane. It carries the smallest cargo out of the choices.<n><n>### Rationale: Airplane. For all other methods, the weight of the cargo is less than a third of the total weight.<n><n>### Input & response:<n>![Airplane.png](ex_1.png)<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>### Demostration:<n><n>Answer:<n>- Input: What is the difference in their ages?<n>- Demostration: The difference in their ages is $ = 4 years.<n><n>Answer:<n>Input: What is the age of the daughter?<n>Answer: She's $ = 12 years old.<n><n>Answer: <n>Input: What is Hurley's age?<n>Answer: Hurley's age is $ = 10 years old.<n><n>### Difficult Level<n><n>### Expectation Levels<n><n><n>**Level A Expectation:**<n><n>### Instruct & Demonstrate:<n><n>- Input:<n>- Answer:<n><n>### Rationalization Level:<n><n>### Input Level:<n><n>## Expectation Levels:<n><n>

Let T represent the number of times you wish to subtract, t represents the total number of digits of your number, and r represents if the number ends in a "1" and you are including it or not.<n>This is what you would use:<n>1) To calculate the number of words in "trouble":<n>```<n>t = 10<n>r = 1<n>```<n>2) To calculate the number you divide by when deciding if you subtract 1 or 2:<n>```<n>t = num / t<n>```<n>3) For the number of times you subtract:<n>```<n>T = (num - r) / t % t + r<n>```<n>4) For the number of digits:<n>```<n>t / 2<n>```<n><n>To check your answer, run this on paper:<n>```<n>1) divide by the number so far<n>2) multiply by 10<n>```<n><n>### Input <n><n>### Response <n><n>### Input How many words need to be spelled to spell the word "happy"?<n><n>### Demolation Input:<n>To spell the word "happY", you have to spell "hap", "hapPY"<n><n>### Response Input:<n><n>### Instruption:<n>Write a response that appropriately selects the sentence closest to the prompt.<n><n>### Prep:<n>You are ready to build your first application!<n><n>### Demo:<n>Firstly, you need a package to use in your application. In the command line, you need to tell npm to list the modules available to you. You

Choices:  A: tropics B: nightmare C: wyoming D: bushes E: feild<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n>### Instructions:Add two numbers<n><n>### Instruc:What number does she get? 5+7<n>### Instru:Add another number to it.4+9<n>### Instruccion:What is the sum of all the numbers? 18<n><n>### Instrutcion: What numbers should they input?<n>### 1st digit: 0<n>### 2nd digit: 1<n>### 3rd digit: 2<n>### Add the next 3 digits<n>### Add the last 2 digits. <n>### Instruccione:What is the sum?<n>### Expected answer: 3<n><n>### Instructed:If you add a dollar to $447, how much will it be if you add another dollar? It should be $(448+7) = $455. This isn't a math homework... just having people write out the calculations is just boring.<n>### Instrucciones:What will be the answer? $(448 + 7)$<n><n>### Instuctianes:A customer will need to order $918 worth of books over the year. One way to track and calculate the order is by summing the total of how much the books cost for each week.<n>### Instructiones:What numbers should the customer input?<n>### Input: Total Weekly books ordered for a year<n>### 1: 455<n>### 2: 30<n>### 1+2 = 485<n>### The total of the numbers ordered should be 485. <n>### Respuesta:El cliente tiene que ingresar 485.<n><n>### Input<n>### What are the total of $485 in the week of 1 and 2.<n>### Total for the week = 485/ 7 = $69.14<n>### If he ordered that amount for the whole year, what would the total yearly amount be? <n>### Total for a year = 69.14 x 52 = $3626.76<n>### <n>### Instructianes:What is the sum for the year? 3626.<n><n>##

If 23 students have blonde hair, how many total students are there?<n><n>### What is the total number of students in the class?<n><n>### Total number of students  = (55 - 20) + 23<n>### Total number  of students = 34<n><n>### Input                   : There are 30 students in a class. 22 of them have white socks. 44 of them have pink shirts. How many students in the class both have white socks and pink shirts?<n><n>###  How many students match both socks and shirts?<n>### Total number + 22 + 44 students in class<n>### Total number students = (30 - 22) + 44<n>### Total number = 12<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The difference in ages between Richard and Hurley is 20. If Hurley is 14 years old, what are their combined ages 40 years from now?<n>Answer: 128<n><n>Input: Pablo’s mother agrees to pay him one cent for every page he reads. He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. Choices: <n>A) a bird <n>B) a word<n>C) a car<n>D) a plane<n><n>Answer: A<n><n>### Demostration: <n>Input: In math class the teacher tells the students that if the average of a number's digits is divisible by 2, then the number itself is also divisible by 2. Is 11 divisible by 2?<n><n>Answer: No<n><n>### Instructions:Use the following code to write a function in C# that can be used to determine whether a square is a 9-square.<n>```<n>    static bool Is9Square(int[,] square) {<n>    int row = 0;<n>    do {<n>      row++;<n><n>        if (square[row,0] + square[row,1] + square[row,-1] + square[0,row] + square[row-1] +   square[row+1, 0] + square[0,-row] + square[-row, 0] +   square[-row+1] > 9)<n>          Continue;<n>}<n>}<n>return row == 9;<n>```<n><n>``` <n>    static bool Is3Square(int[, ] square)<n>    {<n>        int r = 0;<n>    <n>        while (r++<3)<n>        {<n>             if (square[r,0] + square [ r, 1 ] + square [ r, - 1 ] > 3 )<n>             continue ;<n>            }<n>    <n>        return( 3 == r );<n>    }<n> ```<n>

Choices:  A: hospital B: head C: sick person D: elderly person E: doctor's office<n><n>### Response:		If someone needs to go to the doctor's office or hospital because they are ill, they typically have the experience of a sick person.  If they get sick, they will need to visit someone else who has sickness. They will most likely be diagnosed with the disease at an elderly person's office or in a doctor's office or even at the hospital's doctor's office or clinic. When it comes to people who contract illnesses, they can go to any location.<n><n>### Input Choice:What kind of word is 'the'? Choices: A) noun B) pronoun C) verb D) adjective E) possessive word<n><n>### Response:'The' is a word that can be used as a noun.  The reason why it is a noun is because the word 'the' is used when you are talking about something in the most important way possible, and so it is necessary to describe that word that has importance.<n><n>### Response for Above:If the pronoun 'the' is used, it must be used in the most serious way possible, the word 'the' would not be used when there is just one thing because it doesn't show that it has importance.  There is not any way to express that with the pronoun 'the'.

My wife answered, stating that my favorite dinner was Italian and my favorite dessert was German.<n>I then said that my favorite dessert was Italian and my favorite dinner was German.<n>My parents looked at each other, shaking their heads, then asked each of us again.<n><n>### Response (essential task answer of the above informational description)<n><n>For example:<n><n>```<n>"What’s your favorite dessert?"<n>"My favorite dessert is German"<n>"What’s about your favorite dinner?"<n>"My favorite dinner is Italian"<n>What is your fave dinner?<n>Your Favorite dessert?<n>```<n><n>The mother likes German and Italian, the fave is not a dessert but a dinner. This is what makes the mother confused on what you both said and what your favorite dessert is.<n><n>The fave in the second and third question is not a dessert as the first 3 but is a dinner. That's what makes the mother confused of what and who said what. As you will see we both said the same, but it's about two people and 2 dinners.<n><n>The word 'dinner' is the same as the word 'Fave' in the second and third questions. So it confuses the mother to say that my favorite dessert is Italian when she doesn't have the same answer.<n><n>### Question:<n><n>Which one of the following describes a logical fallacy?<n><n>(A) assuming to know something because the speaker does<n><n>(B) using an incomplete thought to justify taking a course of action<n><n>(C) using an absolute to make an uncertain argument<n><n>(D) using a vague term to avoid taking a stance<n><n>(E) assuming to know something when the speaker doesn't<n><n>The answer that I think should have is: (A) assuming to know<n><n>### Input and response:<n><n>### Input 2:<n><n>"Which one of the

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Choices:  A: pub B: plane C: beer D: store E: fraternity house<n><n>### Response:		<n>In order to answer these types of tasks it’s best to first make a guess that is as unlikely to help you in a guess which helps you learn the correct answer.<n><n>### Input<n>#### A: pub<n>There are many different types of food in pubs but mostly food tends to be a bit heavier, so you probably wouldn't choose fried foods or alcohol.<n><n>#### B: plane<n>There are several other options so this is unlikely to help you learn the correct answer, you probably know that you aren't asking about alcohol in a plane or you wouldn't ask this question.<n><n>#### C: beer<n>Just as it's unlikely that a plane has fried foods it's also unlikely that it has fried foods, so this is also an unlikely guess.<n><n>#### D: Store<n>Stores aren't likely to have alcohol either, so this guess is also unlikely to help you learn if you know that fried foods and alcohol are most likely to come from a pub. You probably shouldn't choose this as a guess.<n><n>#### E: fraternity House<n>This is a much better guess than the other choices, but it's not what you're asking for.<n><n>### Response<n>Although your guesses are different from what the question is asking, you will learn whether or not your guess was the correct one.<n><n>Choices: A, B, C, E; C is the only correct answer because pubs can sell alcohol which is a fried food and alcohol. (the question states that each type is a different answer)<n><n>### Input -<n>I always forget my lunch at school. How many weeks can I go without lunch if there are 36 Fridays in the school year?<n><n><n>### Response -<n>Lunch is something that is brought from home and is meant to last more than one day (it's not something you throw away after use or drink). Lunch is also an item that doesn't need to be prepared every day, so you should choose a longer period of time.<n><n>### Choices: B, D, E, F<n><n>#### B: 12<n>If you throw away or drink every item you consume you wouldn't have any left for the rest of the week.<n><n>#### D, F: 7<n>There is

Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:"There are 10 apples on an apple tree.  Three fall off.  Now there are X apples."  What is this an example of? Choices:  A: park B: coloring book C: garden center D: math problem E: gravity<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>1. A) park<n>    2. B) coloring book<n>    3. C) garden center<n>    4. D) math problem<n>    5. E) gravity<n><n>### Input: There were 4 dogs in the park. 43% of them were barking.<n>How many of the dogs were barking?<n><n>### Response<n><n>The difference in answers between the solution and the student's solution indicates an opportunity to discuss the solution with the student.  In the example above, the student responded with "8".<n><n>The solution is (4x0.43) + (4-x)/100 = 1.72.  Thus (4x0.72) or 3 dogs were barking.  We can use the expression x+y=4 to determine the minimum value of y that will produce a possible solution.  For x=4, the minimum value of y is one.  Thus 43% of the dogs were bobarking.<n><n>If we assume one of the dogs is barking and (4 x.43)  or (3.43) is less than the value the student chose, 43% of 4 or 1.72, then the student's answer would be correct.  If we assume 43% of all of the dogs were borking, we then have an inequality that can be simplified and x is given by<n><n>```<n>x = (4x0.3 x1.<n>```<n><n>where x is approximately 4.  Thus the dog that is barking and the dog that are not barking add to approximately 4.<n>

For instance, if there are 6 presents given, then costOfPresents(6) will give you a value of 19.65460161270623. It also returns how long does it take to complete the calculation for each of the presents.

If Hurley is already 14 years old. What is the sum of both their current ages in the given years? <n><n>### Demostrar:<n>```<n>const edad = {<n>  Richard: 33,<n>  Hurley: 14<n>};<n><n>console.log(<n>  `${edad.Richard} + ${edad.Hurley} = ${edad.Richard + edad.Hurley} is 400 years from now`.<n>);<n>```<n><n>### Input<n><n>```<n>const edades = {<n>  RICARDO: 33, <n>  HURLEY: 14<n>}<n><n>console.log(`${edad.RICARDO} + ${edad.hurley} = ${edades.RICARDO + edades.HURLEY} is 40 years from `);<n>```<n><n>---<n><n>```<n>console.log('The difference in ages between Richard Hurley = 76 and Hurley is 76 <n>What are their combined ages if Hurley is 48 years old?');<n>```<n><n>**Solución**<n><n>```<n>const RICARDO = 33,  const HURLEY = 14;<n><n>console.log('${RICARDO} - ${HURLEY} = ${RICARDO - HURLEY} years from Now ');<n>```<n><n>**Sugerencias**<n><n>### Instrucción: Controles de entrada y salida<n><n>### Tarea: Respuesta del sistema<n><n>### Ejecución<n><n>### Validador:<n><n>### Ejemplo:<n><n>### Solución:

Choices:  A: wedding B: tennis C: closet D: left foot E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n>```html<n><button onclick= "document.getElementById('content').innerHTML=this.getSelected()? 'Choices: '+<n>  [this.getSelected().join(', '),''].join('') : 'Choices:'+ 'The answer is'+ <n>  this.getSelected().join(' ')+ '.' "><n>  <p>Choose Answer Options<n>    </p><n></button><n>```<n><n>### <img class="image_thumbnail" src="https://imgur.com/bqN10OJ.jpg" alt=""/><n>### Expectation:The HTML page should look like the following when clicked.<n><n>### Solution:<n>Below is the HTML generated when asked 'Where must one wear a WHITE shoe?'.<n><n>```html<n><div class="image"><n><img src="./white.png" alt="White" style="height:130px; width:300px;"><n></div><n><p>Choose Answer Option<n></p><n><button onclick="document.getElementById('content1').innerHTML = this.getSelected().<n>choose('Closet','Closet','House')”"><n><n>  <p><n>    Closet<n>    </p> <n>  <p>House<n>    </p></button><n><p><n></p> <n><button onclick="answer.display()"></button><n><n> <div id="content1"><n>  <p>The answer is the Closet</p><n>  <n></div><n>```<n><n><n><n><n># <img class="icon" src="https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/images/static/firefox88.png"<n>style="height:16px; width:16px"> Developer <n><n><n><img class="github-icon" src="https%3A%2F%2Fs3-us-west-1.amazonaws.com%2Ffigma-repo%2Fplugins%2Fsharing%2F2.0.0%2Ficons%2Fgithub.svg"<n>alt="github logo" style="background:transparent"> [Jordan-DeMoss GitHub](https://github.com/jdemoss)<n>

He plans to save the money for some candy. Pablo always checks out books that are exactly 150 pages. After reading his books, he went to the store and bought $15 worth of candy and had $3 leftover. How many books did Pablo read?<n>Answer: 12<n><n>Input: A group of six friends planned to buy a car. The cost of the car is $1700 and they plan to share the cost equally. How much more does each friend have to pay now that Brad isn't participating?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Harper needs to buy teacher appreciation gifts for her children’s teachers.  Her son has 3 different teachers and her daughter has 4.  If she spent $70 on gifts, how much did each gift cost?<n>Answer: 10<n><n>### Input:What place of work might you find a hairpin?
